post_title: The Real Price of Cha1da1 Engineering's High Salary
full_review: Pros: Competitive Compensation: The salary is among the highest in the Bangladeshi software industry. Talented Colleagues: You will work alongside some of the nicest and smartest individuals in the Chaldal Engineering team. Engaging Work: Opportunities to take on significant and interesting projects arise from a very early stage. Knowledgeable CTO: The CTO possesses deep technical knowledge and expertise. Meritocratic Environment: Performance is the primary basis for judgment, and credit for your work is duly given. No Office Politics: The workplace is generally free from office politics. Cons: Compensation and Working Hours: Delayed Salary Payment: Salaries are typically disbursed around the 20th-25th of the following month. High Hours, Lower Effective Rate: While the monthly salary is high, the effective hourly rate can be significantly lower due to the extensive hours required compared to other companies in Bangladesh. There are no fixed work hours; you are expected to work until tasks are completed. Pervasive Overtime: Employees are frequently pushed to work overtime, including on weekends. This is the norm rather than the exception, and there is no additional compensation for these extra hours. Some individuals may even be required to work on Eid day without compensation if critical issues ("alarms") arise. Eid Bonus Structure: The Eid bonus is divided, with half paid before Eid and the other half after. (consider this a feature, so you don't spend all your money before Eid) Work-Life Balance and Leave Policies: Non-Existent Work-Life Balance: Achieving a healthy work-life balance is extremely challenging and not a recognized priority. Restrictive HR Policies: HR policies are notably poor. New employees receive no paid leave (including sick leave or for Eid/Puja celebrations) during their first six months. Any time off for Eid or Puja during this initial period is unpaid. Limited Holiday and Leave Access: Public holidays are not formally observed. Instead, employees receive a fixed number of leave days per year, but obtaining approval for this leave can be very difficult. Employees are often discouraged from taking their entitled leave. Management, Culture, and Work Environment: Intense Work Pressure: Work pressure is immense, with expectations set so high that maintaining a personal life while attempting to meet them becomes nearly impossible. Unrealistic Deadlines: Engineers are often subjected to overly tight or unrealistic deadlines, which are frequently imposed without their consultation or consent. Centralized Decision-Making: The CTO holds a virtual monopoly on decision-making. Team leads are often hesitant to voice dissenting opinions or challenge decisions, even if they perceive the CTO to be mistaken. CTO's Expectation Discrepancy: While highly knowledgeable, the CTO sometimes seems to overlook that not all team members possess his extensive (e.g., 20 years) experience. This can make it challenging to explain why tasks may take longer than he anticipates, as complex issues might appear simpler from his perspective. Limited Authority for Team Leads: Team leads often have more theoretical than practical authority, with minimal input in significant decision-making processes. Excessive Micromanagement: There is a significant degree of micromanagement. Higher management frequently bypasses team leads and direct managers to request updates directly from individual employees. Misaligned Management Focus: Overall management practices appear to be more focused on micromanaging employees rather than proactively addressing their concerns or solving systemic problems. Perceived Favoritism: Management may exhibit bias towards certain favored individuals, who tend to receive greater flexibility regarding work-from-home arrangements, work hours, and leave requests. Job Security Concerns: There is a risk of sudden termination without adequate prior warning or proper compensation. Over-reliance on Technological Solutions: Higher management appears to operate under the conviction that every problem can and should be solved primarily with a technological solution, sometimes overlooking other viable approaches. Negative Public Perception: Cha1da1's brand image is perceived quite negatively among the public, which can sometimes make it uncomfortable for employees to identify themselves with the company. This public sentiment appears to be significantly fueled by issues such as repetitive unsolicited calls. Misaligned Project Motivations: There's a perception that some features and tasks are prioritized more to impress investors rather than to genuinely improve the core business or address customer needs.

post_title: P4tha0 Marketing a trap!
full_review: I'm with P4tha0 for more than 6 years. I've seen this team scattered in 2019 and rise again to glory like a Phoenix. They were one of the best in-house marketing team in the industry back in 2020/21 as it was a very small but full of crack polapan who were passionate about their job. Long story short, management changed~ new leads were hiring to their preferred minions and ultimately it ruined the whole team. Some of the new hirings were so bad that HR actually had to force resign/ fire them! Now a days, it has become a circus where incapable but heavy-weight designating people are continuously trying to showoff their power over juniors. You can see many new job vacancies are going on for the marketing team, but it's a trap! The environment has become so toxic most of the old people are already left and rest of them are looking for a way out. So don't join unless you're pro at ЁЯЫвя╕П or nasty politics!

post_title: friendly environment And Boss was very friendly
full_review: I had the pleasure of working at this company for 3 years. The environment was friendly, and the boss was always supportive. Salaries were consistently paid on time, and whenever I had a personal need, the boss was kind enough to provide early payments around the 15th or 20th of the month. Everyone on the team was cooperative and warm, and I truly appreciated the flexibilityтАФwhether it was an emergency leave or a short-term loan, the support was always there. In one word: unforgettable. I will truly miss the entire team and our amazing boss.

post_title: The good, the improving and why I still enjoy being here
full_review: In my 4+ years with the company, I've experienced a healthy and collaborative work environment. It's a place where a Head of Department and a junior developer can sit side by side without egoтАФleaders are friendly and approachable. Salaries are always on time (only delayed once due to a holiday), and the hybrid work option adds great flexibility. The company recently increased sick leave to 12 days alongside 15 annual leave days. The diverse mix of junior, mid, and senior team members creates a solid ground for learning and career growth. Some of the business team members are genuinely dedicated and work hand-in-hand with Devs and QAs to keep things running. YouтАЩll find flexibility and a healthy work-life balance here if you're skilled and can manage your time. Areas for improvement? Eid bonus, better New Year gifts, slightly higher salary increments, and more investment in research would be appreciated. Every experience can vary by department, but unless youтАЩre extremely unlucky, this is a genuinely great place to work. No place is perfect, but today, I choose to stay positive. Life goes onтАФand so does good work.

post_title: A Titanic in the making
full_review: Once a company known for its culture and ability to attract the best talent in the market, now turned into a ticking time bomb about to go off. Every day someone somewhere around the globe is leaving or is getting fired, management has no idea what to do, has been this way ever since.┬а A big big reason high level directors, managers and team leads worth their salt are leaving before going down with the ship. This is a big no-no for anyone in their mid/high level career because this company can neither provide the growth nor the stability you need, and no it's not something you can overturn with your performance or vigor. There is subtle racism when working with foreign teams, perks of being a low-cost labor from 3rd third-world country, you would never get an invitation to attend the high-level decision making meetings, just a worker assigned to follow orders once they are revealed. All that being said, it is the perfect company for Gen Z peeps in their early career, hardly any micromanagement, insane level of flexibility, salary is really good compared to the country median. Basically anyone who wants to add a few months of job experience in their cv while preparing for abroad, you cannot ask for anything better but beware do fall under the comfort zone trap, before you know it you will either lose chance at a good career or get kicked out randomly and become a floater.

post_title: Caution before joining this company
full_review: The positive reviews you see on Glassdoor are written by employees under pressure from management. This is a third-party company that asks people to leave their permanent jobs with promises of quick placement opportunities. But once you join, they often fail to place you with any client. Later, theyтАЩll terminate your contract without any notice or valid reason, using lame excuses. They have no regard for peopleтАЩs careers and make decisions carelessly. This company wonтАЩt hesitate to dismiss you without valid explanation, acting clueless about the damage theyтАЩre doing to peopleтАЩs careers while pretending everything is fine. When itтАЩs time to let you go, the COO will casually say тАЬI feel very ashamedтАЭ and then wave you off with a тАЬbye byeтАЭ тАФ honestly, they should be the ones feeling truly ashamed. Think twice before getting involved with them. Worst experience ever.

post_title: Great company with good colleagues
full_review: The best part that I like about Optimizely is that its not a 9 to 5 job. You can't clock in and clock out and forget everybody here. You don't even feel like doing that. We spend more time after office together than at office. Conventional companies would call it a family bonding type of thing. In reality, I feel we are a group of buddies who like to work and chill together. Work wise, its a great place to learn the latest tech. One thing that really stands out Opti is how smoothly the DevOps function works with everyone else. It doesnтАЩt feel like DevOps is a separate function here тАФ itтАЩs just part of how the whole team works (and everyone understands what we are doing and what standards we are setting and most importantly, why). This is very different from what I saw at my previous workplace, where we were expected to be the server guys who just slot in a new RAM because some chicken doesn't know how to design scalable stacks. I am new and I am still learning. But I am happy that this is the place where I am getting my exposure.

post_title: Some good colleagues. Good work life balance. Terrible HR. But I guess you can only pick two in this triangle.
full_review: The people here are truly one of the companyтАЩs biggest assets. The engineering talent is top-notch, with colleagues who are not only highly skilled but also supportive and approachable. Whether you're a fresher just starting out or a senior engineer with years of experience, you'll find the environment inclusive and empowering. ThereтАЩs a strong emphasis on continuous learning, and the company as a whole is filled with industry thought leaders. If you know 10 incredible level engineers, there is a good chance 4 of them work at opti now. In 10 years I feel people at opti will be considered mafia of leadership in bd same like paypal people. However, not everything is as bright as it used to be. Over the past year or so, many of the great benefits that once set the company apart and attracted the best talent in the country are gradually being scaled back. In the name of cost-cutting and budget management, some perks that made a real difference to employee morale are being removed. For instance, the company used to offer unlimited paid time off (PTO), a rare and generous policy that helped employees truly disconnect and recharge. Unfortunately, thatтАЩs no longer available тАФ now replaced with a capped PTO policy that feels more traditional and restrictive. What used to be great food now has limits on how many you can eat or even runs out of food (yep, you heard me right). What used to be flexible internet benefits is now cancelled. What used to be great office goodies is now non existent. What used to be great coffee culture now has a machine that needs to rest like it has arthritis. What used to be great budget for team outings now has depreciated like 50% with no adjustment so now its not enough for a team outing. What used to be great company after office hours is now being vilified online by radical religious people that the company somehow hired itself (so its the companys fault not to hire people who are culture fit here). Basically lots of new kamla people who misuse company benefits and speak ill of everything here, but still chakri charbe na because they know there is no better place than this. Sad that the hiring bar is low these days and they will hire literally anybody. This is what happens when there is no HR leadership in place and its run by people in other countries who have no idea of how things work here. You can't have remote HR leadership in a company same as how you can't have remote cleaners. Just doesn't make sense. On the other hand, the frequent firing of staff is also very bad in terms of morale and long term growth. Its safe to say no Japanese company would approve of this, and every US company would love this. If you know, you know. The physical office space is also beginning to show signs of strain. While remote work is common and usually prevents overcrowding, there are certain days when many people come in тАФ and thatтАЩs when the limitations become clear. The office isnтАЩt large enough to comfortably accommodate everyone at once, and some employees find themselves without a proper place to sit or have a meeting or simply find some time to think about what is at hand. I read someone commenting that the infrastructure hasnтАЩt kept up with the growth of the company and its very true. In summary, this is still a great place to work, especially for those who value strong engineering culture, flexibility, and a community of talented peers. But itтАЩs hard to ignore the fact that some of the elements that made it truly exceptional are fading. The hope is that leadership recognizes this trend and takes steps to preserve what made the company special in the first place. You can't cost cut your way out of everything. Good culture and good people make a real difference, and they aren't cheap. Also, please stop hiring people who clearly have no respect for people who dont prescribe to the same religious views and aren't a culture fit in an international company.

comments.comment_text: A good review. I agree with the points mentioned about hiring individuals who are not culturally fit.

post_title: The Unmissable Dot
full_review: In terms of the office environment, work-life balance, and available resources, there is hardly any room for dissatisfaction. The tech teamтАФboth the lead and each team memberтАФare very friendly and supportive. The products they have worked on are also quite interesting and engaging. One of the best parts of working here is the team cultureтАФwe often share food, enjoy casual gossip together, and even participate in sports and other fun activities, which makes the workplace lively and enjoyable. However, the company has been facing a persistent issueтАФ salary delays for the past three years тАФwhich is increasingly becoming a source of frustration for many of the employees. ItтАЩs a concern that affects overall motivation and morale. Hope that the management takes this issue seriously and addresses it soon for the well-being and retention of its talented team.

post_title: Systematic Harm and No Room to Grow: Life at BanguJobs.com
full_review: 1. The office environment is not good. They donтАЩt have their own washrooms and have to share dirty common ones. There's very little space for eating, and no access to wash your hands there. The admin also loves to watch employees through CCTV, as part of the CEO's tyrannical empire. 2. CEO (Chief Exploitation Officer) тАУ vocal for the oppressed in linkedin, companyтАЩs tyrant-in-chief, he is a person who does not have time or respect for his employees. There is a certain bottleneck here-every decision has to be made by the CEO, and heтАЩs a busy guy. He canтАЩt even approve his employeesтАЩ increments for over a year. 3. No senior recruitment тАУ They hire trainees at a low salary and treat them like crap. Although people donтАЩt stay here for long, the good ones try to leave the company from the start. 4. Team leads are the only ones staying here for a long time тАУ And that's not a compliment. They're all trinkets with minimal knowledge of technologies. The head of product? Pathetic guy. He has a knack for pleasing the CEO at any cost. All of them excel at controlling juniors, making up weird rules for their subordinates. They are the generals of the CEO's tyrant empire. 5. No Scrum, no Jira, no project management, just endless, boring meetings that kill productivity. And thereтАЩs no useful documentation from the product team side. These stupids have little to no clue how to properly communicate with developers. No sprints either, just vague timelines and the expectation that developers will somehow pull off unrealistic development times. 6. If there is a government holiday after the weekend, they cancel it and force employees to work on the holiday. They don't like employees asking for leave. There's a guy, the head of development, who has no sense and disturbs employees even when they're on leave by making call, text.

post_title: Welcome to the Blame Station 23
full_review: Mogoj Station 23 might look like a tech powerhouse from the outside тАФ big name, many projects, global clients, and a cool vibe. But once you step inside, you realize itтАЩs less of a unified company and more of a bunch of SBUs ( small business units) stitched together with a fancy logo. Each one runs like its own little startup, with its own rules, leadership, and chaos level. To be fair, not all SBUs are bad. Some areтАж fine. Not toxic, not great тАФ just average. You do your tasks, survive your meetings, and go home. No one yells, but no one really helps either. You float. You exist. But hereтАЩs the real issue: across the board, thereтАЩs very little focus on actual growth . No real mentorship No proper career path No structured learning No recognition unless you're part of the " oil club" And bonuses/ promotions? LetтАЩs just say, donтАЩt hold your breath In some SBUs, it gets worse тАФ with seniors who act like juniors are here to serve them, not learn. Their main job? Blame downwards, praise upwards, and pretend to be busy only when the boss shows up. YouтАЩll often see people running around with open laptops like theyтАЩre hacking into NASA, but the second the manager leaves, itтАЩs back to chilling and blaming juniors for literally everything тАФ even bugs they never touched. So, if you're thinking of joining BS23: You might land in a tolerable team and justтАж coast Or, you might find yourself stuck in a loop of thankless work, minimal learning, and zero recognition Either way, donтАЩt expect to grow much . YouтАЩll get tasks, but not direction. Work, but not wisdom. Deadlines, but not development. ItтАЩs not a horror story тАФ just a slow burn where your motivation quietly disappears, and one day you realizeтАж your career hasnтАЩt moved at all.

To the last person who commented regarding food in Ramadan, If you do have complain on the iftar item that's fair. but what's your beef with other muslim people who're not fasting? isn't that their personal choice? also the lunch provided during ramadan was just lunch as usual, nothing fancy.┬а
I'd suggest you 2 things

if you're unhapyy with the iftar provided, raise it to your EM/hr
Get a life

Yes, I believe part of the issue is that Engineering Managers (EMs) may not have a full understanding of all the engineers or developers under them. This can lead to misunderstandings. Some developers are doing exceptionally well, and others, while highly skilled, may be working in a limited tech stack based on project needs. Unfortunately, theyтАЩre often judged solely on that stack, rather than their full capabilities.
IтАЩve noticed that some developers are actually capable of much more than their current roles reflect. However, this potential is sometimes overlookedтАФpossibly due to a lack of direct communication. It seems that EMs may rely mainly on feedback from team leads or maybe just a small communication, which doesnтАЩt always provide a complete picture. This could be contributing to this discrimination or unfair evaluations.
I believe that if EMs made an effort to get to know each developer more directly or maybe knowing them well, they would gain better insights into their strengths and contributions. This could lead to more balanced recognition and a more supportive work environment.

Totally agreeing with the whole thing. Another point I felt really disturbing is providing different foods in lunch during whole ramadan in lunch but very poor food in iftar. It feels really weird to me. Why the people who are not fasting ( not counting the people from other religion here respectfully ) is enjoying their lunch time very much comparing to regular day lunch whereas the people who stays in office during iftar due to workload is getting very poor food.┬а

I can see you've chosen to raise several concerns about your company anonymously on a public platform instead of addressing them directly with your HR or reporting manager or lead. That raises an important question: is it a lack of confidence or willingness on your part to seek answers internally, or does it reflect a company culture where even senior engineers feel unsafe or unheard when voicing concerns?
┬а
For instance, if the coffee machine is broken or if there are issues with other amenities, whatтАЩs stopping you from simply asking HR for clarification or resolution? These seem like questions that should be easily addressed internally - especially by someone in your position.
┬а
By choosing to speculate publicly rather than engaging in open dialogue within the company, it unfortunately highlights a missed opportunity for leadership. Leadership isn't just about writing great code; itтАЩs also about taking initiative, seeking clarity, and fostering positive change - especially when something seems off.
┬а
IтАЩm not from your organization, but I felt compelled to share this perspective. Reflection is key to growth. If you're aspiring to lead, start by being proactive where it matters. Just my two cents.

!True
True indeed. Been there done that. Need to do to keep going. But good thing is they listens and tries to accommodate which obviously takes time!

To the person who commented below :

Those who have office working days obviously deserve good foods , for example mutton. But people who are working on regular office working days also deserve it. It is really clear that good food ( which doesnt taste good to me though ) is served only on wed and thursday. SO only those who are working on WFH days are getting it, not everyone. If it was given on one office day and one WFH day then atleast I think your point to "cover up all the teams" would have justfied. Not all teams are present on Wednesday or thursday and I can bet on that.
There have been teams where the work is really outdated. Changing stacks are fine, no one is complaining about it. But in 2025 if you are given to work on a stack which was popular on back in 2013 but is almost died now, doesn't it feel irritating and bad for your career growth?┬а

┬а

Few insights about cons. And all are solely my personal opinion.

Cefalo doesn't want to fill pockets by food whether that's lunch or coffee. About lunch we have a number of teams whose working days are different than the rest. So don't they as well deserve good food? That's the reason behind arranging special items on two different days to cover up all the teams. Now about coffee, Nescafe Gold is out of stock from where they used to source and its really unfortunate that our coffee machine has gone for maintenance at the same time. If we can share a source from where they can get the large volume of Nescafe Gold it will be back ASAP.
┬а
It is somewhat true. At the end they got to keep it going. But IMHO they at least gives it a thought before bringing any clients. Cefalo did have a huge opportunity of a client requiring hardware technical expertise. They could have simply bring in that but they didn't. Cefalo do assign its engineers to different tech stacks but before doing so they consult first with that person and based upon the mindset/agility they proceed or not. If not Cefalo if someone were to stick to just specific tech stack for the rest of the life then it better be a T. REX!
I feel you bruh/sissy! No: Profit Sharing, GF, PF, 13th Month Salary, 2x Overtime Pay, Onboarding!
The best review I must say.

post_title: Banglar Google
full_review: The CEO hired people saying, "We will show people that Bangladeshi developers can build world class project and we will be Banglar Google." It became a company of 100+ people. The product was decent as a first digital wallet of Bangladesh. But, it failed due to bad decisions of management. Lot's of employees didn't receive salary of 3/4 months and they even didn't pay tax slips of employees for an entire financial year though they have deducted the tax from the salary. During covid, they just suddenly stopped communicating to the employees. The dream of building "Banglar Google" ultimately became Baanglaar Gu.. Gol

post_title: Empowering and Accessible Leadership
full_review: One thing IтАЩve always admired about Cefalo is how grounded and supportive our leadership team is. Despite the companyтАЩs growth, our leaders remain approachable and genuinely interested in our ideas and challenges. They donтАЩt just lead from the topтАФthey mentor, listen, and inspire from within. Their vision has created a workplace where everyone feels included and empowered.

post_title: A Cautionary Tale for Interns and Developers
full_review: A Harsh Reality тАУ More Like┬а "Intern Solutions" I want to highlight some of the major issues IтАЩve witnessed: Exploitation of Interns: The management often hires interns and places them under immense pressure to meet tight client deadlines. In many cases, entire projects are handed over to interns with little to no senior oversight. After 3-4 months of overwork, these interns are dismissed without any real consideration or offer of permanent employment. ItтАЩs no surprise that many people now refer to the company as "Intern Solutions". Unethical Work Culture: Interns are led to believe that good performance might lead to permanent roles. However, under the leadership of PM, this turns out to be a false hope. Interns are routinely forced to work 12тАУ15 hours per day, often handling the responsibilities of full-time developers. Despite this, they are paid only 6000 BDT, with no overtime compensation or weekend pay. Lack of Accountability Among Senior Staff: Senior developers, particularly Frontend Lead, frequently avoid their responsibilities. Common excuses like "no electricity" are used to skip workdays, while in reality, they go shopping or take naps during working hours. This behavior leaves junior developers and interns to carry the workload. When deliverables are delayed, CEO blames the remaining developers instead of addressing the root of the problem. Toxic Team Dynamics: Developers like frontend lead, involved in component development, often waste significant time without producing results. Their inefficiency causes delays that impact the whole team. Yet, they escape accountability while others are pressured to clean up the mess. Final Thoughts: company needs to seriously rethink its values and treatment of interns and junior developers. If you're considering joining this company, especially as an intern, be very cautious. DonтАЩt be fooled by empty promises. The managementтАЩs lack of ethics and the senior staffтАЩs irresponsibility create an extremely unfair and demotivating work environment.

full_review: Some Departments are very royal in their own terms. They have got decent flexibility, salary, bonus and monthly incentives. Management simply does not want to "waste (!!)" dimes here, where nothing(!!) gets produced and does not get any sales ! So you should have guessed by now . But software teams create softwares which ultimately decrease operation time and increase efficiency by reducing cost yet nobody cares (Well, somebody from top management cares but his family members does not) !! How about environment ? The workplaces are two types, one is in corporate and another is in factory. Corporate is crammed and Factory is beautiful and wide open. But how about office culture? If you are in corporate side, well you will be constantly be aware of politics, nepotism and two-faced people. Does it happen in the factory too? Yes (same company after all), but not that much, people here are mostly friendly. You can roam around flexibly in the industrial area with dedicated transport only for IT persons. Overall you won't be micro-managed and can roam around if you want. But you won't find much great minds in this ржорзБрж▓рж╛рж░ ржХрзНрж╖рзНржпрж╛ржд. How about growth ? If you are very curious CSE fresher looking to learn new technologies from good mentors, well good luck with that. Ancient tech-stacks with weird system operations are here for you. Great people don't stay here for too long and you won't find here that many. If you can learn on your own, then you might find some great hardwares here. But I can not guarantee if those will be enough to keep you motivated for long. Because there is no other alternative for good mentors. And if you stay here for too long, you will discover yourself as a ржХрзБрзЯрзЛрж░ ржмрзНржпрж╛ржЩ just like others in the same shithole. YouтАЩll get comfortable, enjoy the moment, and one day the frying pan will be too hot to jump out of.

post_title: Good Culture with Lots of Injustice and Deception
full_review: Stable and timely salary, good amount (100-300k BDT) Generous yearly profit-sharing (approximately тВ╣2 lakh). Two festival bonuses per year. All government holidays off, plus two-day weekends. Free office lunch and transportation. Government-approved sick and casual leave, along with 10 cashable vacation days. Modern and luxurious office space located in Gulshan 1. Ethical concern: According to some Islamic scholars, the income may be considered non-compliant due to involvement in the US healthcare insurance sector, which is linked to interest-based (usury) models. Recruitment transparency is lacking: Highly qualified candidates are often hired under one job title but assigned to unrelated and less meaningful roles, which can negatively impact career growth. You might be hired for a Python role but the work might end up being AWS cloud management. <DANGEROUS> Internal politics and conflict: There is a noticeable divide between junior and senior employees, creating a hostile work environment. Poor managerial oversight: Due to weak supervision from US-based leadership, local managers may misuse authority, leading to toxic interactionsтАФthough company policy does not permit outright abuse. Unprofessional culture: Expect unkind or rude behavior from some senior staff. Time-off challenges: Vacation days are difficult to utilize in full, with approvals being rare/toxic beyond sick leaves. No job security: Salaries are routed through a third-party entity not clearly tied to the parent company (Veradigm), raising legal and stability concerns. Absence of a dedicated HR team makes it hard to address misconduct or improve workplace culture effectively. The company offers solid compensation and benefits, along with a modern workplace. However, serious concerns exist regarding ethical alignment, role clarity, internal conflicts, and managerial accountability. Great culture potentialтАФbut undermined by poor leadership and toxic individuals.

post_title: Puppets & Liabilities
full_review: You canтАЩt even dare to bring up their unfair and exploitative salary system. As long as you stay silent and keep working like a machine, they will keep using you. The moment you find the courage to speak about a well-deserved increment, the CEO and his circle of loyal puppets will instantly start making you feel like youтАЩve done nothing for the company. The CEO has a favorite line he throws around like a script: "See, I considered you an asset to this company, but now you're trying to become a liability. DonтАЩt talk to me about increments." In their distorted logic: If you silently accept a pathetic salary of 6,000 to 10,000 as a Junior Software EngineerтАФwhile managing 3-4 projectsтАФyouтАЩre praised as an тАШasset.тАЩ But the moment you raise your voice for fair pay, you suddenly become a 'liability.' The toxicity doesnтАЩt stop at the top: Many employees turn into puppets of the CEO. They engage in cheap office politics to please management. Whenever someone tries to speak up for their rights, these so-called colleagues: Try to break your confidence. Make you doubt your own worth. Act as the CEOтАЩs mouthpiece to silence you. All so they can protect their own seats and earn brownie points from the CEO. They even use cheap tactics like: Threatening to hold back your salary for being late, while pretending to forget youтАЩve worked countless late nights for their clients. If you miss their calls on your day off, they make you feel like youтАЩve committed a crime. They love to act like they are employee-friendly, but the reality is completely different: ThereтАЩs not even an IPS (backup power system), though the company handles multiple projects and clearly doesnтАЩt lack work. At the end of the day, itтАЩs a suffocating, manipulative, and toxic work environment where both management and these puppet employees exploit hardworking people in the name of тАШcompany culture.тАЩ

post_title: A Toxic Family-Run Circus Disguised as a Company
full_review: This isnтАЩt a companyтАФitтАЩs a family-run disaster. Nearly every employee is a cousin, sibling, or distant relative. If you're not part of their bloodline, you're nothing more than disposable labor. The so-called CEO operates remotely from the UK, pretending to lead a global business merger while exploiting cheap Bangladeshi workers who carry the entire workload without fair compensation, appreciation, or timely pay. Salaries are constantly delayed with recycled excuses, and raises are a fantasy unless you're a relative or a shameless bootlicker. Promotions arenтАЩt based on performance or skillтАФtheyтАЩre based on who you're related to or how well you can suck up to management. The hiring process is laughable. Interviews exist only to maintain a facade. If you're not already тАЬinтАЭ with the family or one of their minions, youтАЩre wasting your time. Most decisions are made behind closed doors with zero transparency or fairness. The company is infested with toxic employees whose only talent is flattery. These leeches secure permanent positions while hardworking, talented staff are ignored, mistreated, or pushed out. ThereтАЩs constant verbal abuse, public humiliation, and no HR accountabilityтАФbecause HR is just another family puppet who makes and breaks rules on a whim. The companyтАЩs leadership is a complete farce. Two brothers act as co-owners, but their incompetence and lack of integrity are glaring. They preach about professionalism, but their actions reflect pure hypocrisy. They create strict policies only to break them for themselves and their favorites. Recently, they promoted another unqualified cousin to the role of C00. This individual lacks basic manners, education, or leadership qualitiesтАФbut got the job solely through nepotism. He now walks around barking orders with no clue how to lead. Employee benefits? Another joke. тАЬUnlimited coffeeтАЭ turns into monthly salary deductions if you drink more than two cups a day. Lunch? Controlled with petty rules. Time off? If youтАЩre family, you get it without question. If not, good luck getting approved. If a relative called G4ND00 leaves and goes abroad, they can return months later and be reinstated immediately. But for others, even a one-week gap means :D┬а no chance of return. This company operates on favoritism, manipulation, and exploitation. There's no clear vision, no ethical foundation, and absolutely no long-term potential. It's a classic example of how nepotism in business creates a toxic, demoralizing, and completely broken workplaceтАФwhere real talent is ignored and incompetence rises to the top.

post_title: Pr!yoSh0p = PriyoGarments
full_review: If you're someone looking to build a long-term career in a structured, growth-oriented, and employee-friendly environment, Pr!yoSh0p may not be the ideal place for you. 1) Despite being a tech-driven organization, employees, even those in technical roles, are often treated like sales personnel. The workload can feel like youтАЩre expected to perform the job of five people simultaneously. 2) Mistakes, even minor ones, are treated disproportionately harshly. Personal life often takes a back seat, and taking leave, especially for significant life events like marriage, can be extremely difficult. While most companies offer a week or more for marital leave, at Pr!yoSh0p, getting more than three days off can feel like a battle. 3) The physical work environment also leaves much to be desired. In summary, Pr!yoSh0p may not be suitable for professionals who value work-life balance, fair treatment, structured growth, and a supportive work culture. Proceed with caution if you're considering building your career there.

post_title: A Candid Look Inside Truck Dorkar тАУ From a Once-Thriving Tech Hub to a Company in Decline
full_review: Rcently, I noticed that Truck Dorkar h as received some negative attention on platforms like *Deshi Mula*. In response, it seems the company is attempting to counter that criticism with a series of overly positiveтАФand possibly fabricatedтАФreviews on Glassdoor. I believe itтАЩs important to share an honest and balanced perspective of the actual situation within the company. The Golden Days of the Tech Team There was a time when Truck Dorkar was a vibrant hub for talented engineers and product thinkers. The tech team, composed of passionate, curious, and hard-working individuals, built a unique culture from the ground up. Many were fresh graduates who quickly grew through hands-on experience, learning from one another and pushing the boundaries of what a small team could achieve. Under the leadership of the CTO, the team thrived in an environment that felt more like a family than a workplace. Though there were few additional perks, the regular salary payments, team outings, and in-office celebrations helped form strong bonds among colleagues. The CTOтАЩs open-door policy fostered trust and encouraged individuals to voice ideas and concerns. This culture of collaboration made Truck Dorkar a standout place to work for many engineers. One of the best practices during those times was the annual salary increment for the tech team. While not always perfect, the processтАФdriven by the tech leads and тАФensured that contributions were recognized, making it one of the more rewarding tech workplaces compared to others in the industry. The Beginning of the Decline Unfortunately, things began to change with the arrival of a new Head of HR. His management approach introduced rigid and demotivating policies, despite the company offering no additional facilities beyond the monthly salary. He disrupted the previously smooth salary increment process, often delaying reviews and responding unprofessionally to employees who raised concerns. Telling valued team members to тАЬfind another jobтАЭ simply for seeking fair compensation was not only disrespectful but deeply damaging to morale. This marked the beginning of the breakdown of a once-solid culture. Product Leadership Shift and Disconnect The departure of the former VP of Product further accelerated the decline. Under her leadership, the product and tech teams worked closely and harmoniously. After she left, the relationship between the two teams deteriorated, and the company saw a series of unsuccessful product launches. The lack of strategic direction and synergy hurt the tech teamтАЩs momentum and motivation. Final Downfall and Talent Exodus In recent months, the situation has worsened. The CEO consistently failed to deliver on promises regarding salary revisions and increments, leading to a growing mistrust among the employees. Morale plummeted, and many talented individuals began to question their future with the company. One defining moment was when the lead of the app team took a stand over unfulfilled commitments. Instead of engaging constructively, management responded harshlyтАФdespite her significant contributions. This led to a wave of resignations, including that of the CTO, marking the end of an era. Today, the remaining team members are disillusioned, actively seeking better opportunities. ItтАЩs heartbreaking to see such a once-promising and inspiring workplace decline so sharply due to poor HR practices, non-technical decision-making, and a lack of appreciation for the tech teamтАЩs efforts. A Word to Future Employers and Current Management To anyone hiringтАФif you come across former Truck Dorkar engineers, know that youтАЩre looking at smart, hard-working, and genuinely collaborative people. They deserve better environments and will surely add great value wherever they go. To the current managementтАФthere may still be time to turn things around. But that requires humility, a return to people-first leadership, and a commitment to rebuild trust with the remaining employees. If things continue as they are, itтАЩs only a matter of time before W e the last of the committed employees decide to leave as well.

post_title: Review
full_review: Review: Pros: Salary is provided timely, though there may be occasional delays. Co-workers are generally helpful and supportive. Cons: The work environment is highly toxic, which makes it difficult to thrive. No clear HR or work policies, leading to confusion and lack of structure. Overtime is frequent and there's constant pressure to complete projects in very short timelines. The company doesn't allocate enough time to finish projects properly. Sometimes employees are forced to attend the office even on weekends. Salary increments are severely delayed and the provided salary is not sufficient. The CTO's behavior is unpredictable while he can be normal at times, there are instances of extreme misbehavior without any apparent reason.

post_title: This is not a company it's a Circus
full_review: I joined this company over two years ago, and hereтАЩs my honest experience. Pros: 1. Salary is always on time. 2. You can learn skills for yourselfтАФonly for your personal growth. ThatтАЩs it. Now letтАЩs talk about the Cons, which honestly feel endless. So here it comes: 1. The Managers тАУ Completely unqualified, unprofessional, and have no idea what theyтАЩre doing. Every developer here knows how outdated and clueless they are. They just throw random tasks around without understanding anything. Total joke. 2. The Management тАУ Another level of disaster. Outdated mindset, zero professionalism. One of them has random mood swings and starts shouting over the most trivial stuff. Tho the CTO as a person is quite nice, but in terms of leadership? Meh. Now this one deserves a drumroll тАУ the most corrupted department in the company тАУ 3. ЁЯЧгя╕ПЁЯОЩя╕П THE SQA DEPARTMENT. They literally have a full floor to themselves. And trust me, most of them joined with only one qualification: their face. ThatтАЩs it. No skills, no brains тАУ nothing. I know some of them personally and they donтАЩt even have this. And skills? DonтАЩt even ask. They donтАЩt know jack about automation. Half of them donтАЩt even understand how software works. Over 50 people in that department doing God knows what. Full-on circus. 4. IT Department тАУ They walk around like they're some tech gods. Reality? Skills so basic that if they didnтАЩt have this job, theyтАЩd probably be fixing Wi-Fi routers or working as local mechanics. No respect, no mannersтАФnothing. 5. HR Department тАУ I don't want to start, but thak mukh ta kharap na kori. No brains. If they ask you for a document, be prepared to submit it 5-6 times and theyтАЩll still come asking. Unbelievably unprofessional. They delay increments, they forget things constantly. And recruitment? Clueless. The accountant acts like heтАЩs some high-level government babu. Full-on garbage attitude. Talking about increment? These guys only look at the years of experience. I have no idea how they hire. 6. DevOps Team тАУ If they think theyтАЩre DevOps, then trust me, I could be their team lead with one hand tied. They're stuck in 1990s technology. Every time you suggest something newтАФ"Security issue", "too expensive", "too modern", bla bla bla. They are so outdated it's embarrassing. Honestly, I have serious doubts if the CDO even studied anything related to tech. 7. If you actually have skillsтАФyouтАЩll be ignored. Every year, a pity 10K increment. But if youтАЩre good at licking boots, congratulations againтАФyouтАЩre climbing up the ladder fast. No need for skills, just chaapar jor. I've seen so-called тАЬSenior Software EngineersтАЭ who barely have the skills of a trainee. Still, IтАЩll be fairтАФthere are a few genuinely talented people here. And honestly, they are the only reason this company is still standing. So yeah, if you want to grow for yourself, learn some tech for your own future, then maybe it's worth staying. But if youтАЩre expecting decent salary, good leadership, or even basic professionalismтАФbhule jao. You ainтАЩt getting any of that here.

post_title: рждрзЗрж▓ржмрж╛ржЬ ржПржоржкрзНрж▓рзЯрзА
Garbage
full_review: I had a very disappointing experience working at this company. The HR, Admin, and Accounts departments lack basic professionalism. Most of them donтАЩt even know how to properly do their jobs. HR has no decision-making power and simply follows whatever Accounts says. The Admin team is always focused on cutting employee benefits to reduce company expenses. The Accounts department spends more time pointing fingers at others than doing their own work. There is only one day off per week, and even that doesnтАЩt feel like proper rest. There are no benefits, no extra allowances, and nothing that supports employee well-being. Management lacks planning, coordination, and vision. The overall work culture is toxic and inhumane.

post_title: ржмрж╛ржЗрж░рзЗ ржлрж┐ржЯржлрж╛ржЯ, ржнрж┐рждрж░рзЗ рж╕ржжрж░ржШрж╛ржЯ
full_review: The company has seen a significant decline following the resignation or reassignment of several changemakers, largely due to persistent internal politics. The current management in Bangladesh demonstrates a lack of empathy. For example, public holidays declared during Eid and Buddha Purnima were not honored. Employees were required to work from home on these days without any form of compensation. Furthermore, although Tuesdays are typically work-from-home days, employees are compelled to work from the office if there's a public holiday that week. Certain senior employees тАФ including some in top management тАФ consistently avoid taking ownership of their mistakes and tend to shift blame onto others. Some workaholic employees create a toxic atmosphere by imposing their intense work habits on others, making it extremely difficult to collaborate effectively. Members of the top management have been disconnected from hands-on development for over a decade. One individual in particular is notably resistant to new ideas or technologies and insists on giving opinions on topics outside his expertise, often hindering progress. The HR processes are outdated. The company does not provide pay slips, promotion letters, or formal documentation of salary revisions, which is surprising for an organization of this size. While food is often cited as a company perk, the quality is consistently poor. Many employees have reported stomach issues or illness after eating in the office cafeteria. Overall, the work environment lacks the positivity and support needed for employee well-being. The culture contributes to stress, burnout, and low morale, leaving little motivation to come into the office.

comments.comment_text: True

post_title: Toxic and Incompetent Management
full_review: The environment of Tech Team of 5hareTr!p is an absolute dumpsterfire and it has been like this for over a year now. This is what happens when you give the title of cto to someone who doesn't deserve it. Ever since the new cto took over the senior developers have been leaving one by one. The entire team was managed like it was a garments factory, only yelling and blaming. Day by day the new cto built up a culture of finger pointing one another. If there was an issue someone needs to be blamed and some team needs to be yelled at. And the yelling was absolute street level as well. Using sland language for senior developer and team leads, while standing in front of their teams. One day the entire Tech Team was holding a meeting and the cto told us that "we don't need senior developers, we can do with highly motivated juniors. I had experience before and now the experience has only grown". These two lines describe the cto's every day interaction with the team. Regarding anything, whether it's being late, or there is a deadline to meet, or there was a miscommunication within different teams, all of it was addressed by aggression and yelling and talking down to the seniors. If someone is in desperate need of a job then you can consider this company, as the seniors and team themselves are not toxic but actually very co operative. But the entire management, from the two ceos to the boot licking department heads, are absolute garbage.

post_title: Sesh jamanar ajab.
full_review: Ki diye shuru kore kemne sesh korbo bujhtesina, list diye sesh kora jabe na. But company eto kichur poreo kemne market a tike ache dekhe obak lage! A Company wih lots of lies. Raw PHP without structure. (Framwork banaise 3 ta folder diye, Model, View r Controller kintu vitore jinis eki. ) They run their system using an Engine! xD Je line lagbe na, comment koro! delete kora nisedh. Kintu data ke edit korlo delete korlo egular abar log thake nah. Ambitionless Ekta company. Boro kono kisu korar shahosh or capability kono kisu nai. Intern r fresher der mittha asshash dekhaiyaney. Maximum Senior ra COde and structure kisu jane nah(OOP dekhe mukh diye OOPs ber hoy jeno sob oder mathar upor diye jay) Salary will be like dan khoyrat kortese. Increment living in 1990 . bochore 2k-4k highest. Kaj deyar somoy tumi amar asset, increment er somoy liability. Emon ek system banaise jetar moddhe lokkho koti bhul to asei tar upor nijerai ei system use korte voy pay. R ekjon ke eksathe parle 10 ta project chapay diye 2 dinei sob solution aday kore nibe. Ekta kaaj korte naki 2 ghonta lage, to vai apni kore felen, amar to 2 din lagbei! Aro onek kotha ase jegula bolte parle arektu halka lagto, kintu apatoto eitukui mone hoy onek hoise.

post_title: Worst company, CEO and Software Team leader
full_review: In my full career joining this company was the worst decision. And I have paid for that decision. The CEO behavior is totally cruel, and make you feel you are his servant and he has bought your all time. During office time no break no gossip or fun allowed. All the time you have to maintain 4-5 work report, where you have to update your work and time and you have to answer for all of your work report. How time you consume, how much work you have done. He thinks maintaining these several reports nobody would be able to deceive working time. He already got bad reputation for using slang words against another community member. Because of this his personality is well known. The team leader he has appointed who is like a ringmaster of the software team. He overworks his team members to please CEO. In office he literally does nothing. His behavior with his team mates is so unprofessional and hurts everyone with his words. I already had previous company experiences. But I have never seen such a cruel, good for nothing like him. In office most of the time he does his freelance personal work. Even the CEO knows of it but never took any action against him. I wish I could beat the shit out him well. I literally gone to frustration because of him. May Allah punish him because of all the bad deeds he has done. I was got rid from this job because of conflicts with team leader. Anyway it was the worst experience of my life. Such a toxic culture and full of politics here. Stay away from this company and stay safe. Company like this can make your life living hell.

post_title: Unbearable mental torture
full_review: If they know that you are better than them and you don't play by their rules rather than with honesty and dignity they will try to out of the way to crush you. All the departments head post about environment, toxic air in the social media and have zero knowledge about software project management. One worst thing is that your whole team can deceive you and say they can't meet the deadline at the eleventh hour because some top-tier hold the delivery sabotaging the project. Salary review is a joke here. They will do as they like no proper. This company says about corporate culture snd ethics but their morality is long gone.

post_title: Living up to its Reputation тЬи
full_review: ЁЯСЙ Let's start with the GOOD stuffs first - Now what are the CONS ? The answer is ' It Depends ' As Eno5i5 has over 400+ employees , you might unfortunately end up with toxic group or colleagues or management. It varies on the people you are working with. There is a lot of work load and as the clients are on the other side of the world (mainly North America), maintaining work life balance is pretty tough here especially if you are of the higher positions. The company is very strict with deadlines, so you'll be pushed to the limits. You might not always like the projects you work on. A lot complain about individual performances not being recognized or honored. If you love office provided gifts, parties, celebrations, surprises and picnics, you'll most be disappointed. Obviously, every company has its bad sides. But considering the good stuffs I mentioned, I think it's worth the hassle. Especially if you compare Eno5i5 to the rest of the top software companies in Bangladesh. Always remember, Different people experience differently because they got different perspectives and expectations.

post_title: A Real Look Inside BRAC IT: What Many WonтАЩt Say Out Loud
full_review: 1. Hiring and Promotion ArenтАЩt Always Fair Despite what the official statement says, many people inside BRAC IT feel that hiring and promotions often depend more on personal connections than merit. Teams, especially under certain leaders, are filled with friends and past colleagues. ThereтАЩs no proper performance review system, so itтАЩs hard to understand how promotions are actually decided. 2. Religious Bias May Not Be тАЬOfficial,тАЭ But ItтАЩs There BRAC IT claims to be secular, but some leadership members have openly shown atheist views, and a few have even shared anti-Islamic comments in the past. While personal beliefs are private, the way they influence team culture can make others feel uncomfortable or excluded. 3. Speaking Up IsnтАЩt Always Safe or Easy The company encourages using тАЬproper channelsтАЭ to raise concerns, but what are those, really? Many employees feel thereтАЩs no trusted space to talk about internal problems. Management is aware of these issues but seems unwilling to make changes, and thatтАЩs frustrating when peopleтАЩs careers and livelihoods are at stake. To make things worse, firing people without explanation happens often. We live in constant fear of being let go for no clear reason, and the abuse of power feels like a normal part of the culture. 4. Impact Is Mostly Through BRAC, Not Independent Innovation BRAC IT often talks about making a difference in Bangladesh, but most of that impact comes from being tied to BRAC. Outside of that, there's little innovation happening. The microfinance project, its main offering- is based on interest, which many employees see as conflicting with ethical or religious values. 5. Criticism ShouldnтАЩt Be Dismissed as Hate Yes, no one should spread hate or attack others based on faith. But calling all criticism тАЬhate speechтАЭ is a way to shut down real issues. People just want honesty, fairness, and a healthy work culture, things every organization should take seriously.

full_review: Pros: Salary is paid on time at the end of each month. Paid Leave (PL) is granted after 5 years of service. ЁЯеХ Opportunity to work with cutting-edge technology. Cons: Extremely high-pressure work environment, often under unreasonable individuals. ЁЯдб Many senior employees have left due to declining company policies. Only a few in management remain lap ЁЯРХ, and blind obedience is expected. You'll receive plenty of ЁЯеХ but with strings attached. Rampant internal politics. Product team lacks focus, engages in internal politics, and often blames developers for their own shortcomings. The CTO behaves more like a product manager, rarely supports developers, and encourages sycophancy ЁЯЫвЁЯЫв. Career growth is largely based on flattery. The company has shifted from being tech-driven to being led by operations and CEO mandates. Salary structure is inconsistent. Some individuals with close ties to management receive double the salary for average performance. Interns often remain at the lowest pay grade indefinitely. HR practices are arbitrary. HR personnel get rapid promotions (e.g., 5 times in 4 years), while others face a promotion freeze. HRтАЩs main role is to please management, not support employees. They enforce bizarre rules and rarely resolve real issues. If youтАЩre from SUST or RUET, you may be fast-tracked. Others must go through 4тАУ5 interview rounds with ЁЯдб.

post_title: Worse Company
full_review: Pros: Honestly, there are no real pros here. Besides receiving your basic salary, you get zero additional benefits. Cons: The company has inherited all the worst aspects of Bg!T culture тАФ unsurprising, since many people here came from there. No salary or career development framework exists. Promotions are random, and youтАЩll see people with laughable job titles who clearly donтАЩt understand what those titles mean. The company has two CTOs , but theyтАЩre practically invisible. Management never encourages reaching out to them, and they contribute nothing. Most managers are unqualified and insecure. They avoid hiring competent people out of fear they'll be exposed to upper management. Career growth depends on sucking up to your manager. If your manager is bad, your life will be miserable тАФ expect unpaid overtime, weekend work, and impossible deadlines. Work hours are 9 AM to 7 PM minimum тАФ labor laws donтАЩt seem to apply here. HR is a constant disaster. Salary increments are delayed, and processes are so broken youтАЩll need to fill out the same forms 3тАУ4 times. They say theyтАЩre working on issues тАФ theyтАЩre not. The new office is in a rural area with no working AC. Employees regularly get sick within a few days of working there. Suggesting improvements is risky тАФ if your manager doesnтАЩt like your idea, you could be fired. People are frequently let go without reason. A bunch of random IT guys call themselves тАЬDevOpsтАЭ with almost zero actual knowledge. They follow outdated practices from 20 years ago and resist any modern suggestion. Deployment is a nightmare тАФ you'll have to call them multiple times just to get something pushed to staging. Overtime is the norm, with no recognition or reward тАФ no tours, no team dinners, no appreciation. The BA (Business Analyst) team is basically just technical writers. They're afraid to hire anyone new or more competent. The design team lacks creativity. Most of their work is just copying тАФ no original thought, no innovation. ThereтАЩs a so-called тАЬSecurity SpecialistтАЭ who gives weekly sessions on generic topics like installing antivirus software or avoiding malware. They have no idea how to deal with real application security, vulnerabilities, or security researchers тАФ just the same basic advice on loop every week.

We always welcome constructive criticism and use it as a tool for growth. However, we find it necessary to respond when a review contains misleading, generalized, and borderline defamatory statements aimed at discrediting the hard work of hundreds of professionals who contribute to the success of this company every day.
Let us address the points made with transparency:
No Real Pros
LetтАЩs start with the obvious: salary is paid timely every month, and our employees receive free meals, generous leave, and a stable work environmentтАФsomething many companies in the industry struggle to guarantee. Calling this тАЬzero benefitsтАЭ is simply dishonest.
Inherited Bg!T Culture & Random Promotions
This is a false narrative. Our company has developed its own identity, structure, and work culture over the years. Promotions go through a standardized, performance-based review process and are approved after review by multiple stakeholders. Individuals are promoted based on KPIs, skill contributions, and behaviorтАФnot favoritism.
If someone misunderstood a designation or someoneтАЩs title, thatтАЩs a lack of awarenessтАФnot the companyтАЩs failure.
Two CTOs Contribute Nothing
We wonтАЩt entertain vague attacks on leadership based on assumptions. Our CTOs are responsible for key decision-making on infrastructure, client solutions, and technical architecture. They may not be visible in day-to-day stand-ups, but their impact is very much reflected in our delivery success and growth.
Managers are Unqualified & Promote Insecurity
This kind of blanket statement is both offensive and untrue. Our managers are hired through stringent screeningтАФmany with 5тАУ10+ years of experience across local and international projects. If someone had personal friction with a manager, they had the option to escalate it. But public slander is not how professionals resolve conflict.
Unpaid Overtime, Labor Law Violation
We do not mandate overtimeтАФteams manage their own delivery timelines. In tech companies, occasional stretches happen before releases. To generalize this as labor law violation is misleading.
Our working hours are aligned with industry norms, and weтАЩre continuously improving work-life balance across teams.
HR is a Constant Disaster
While we acknowledge some process delays in the past (especially during transitions like ERP migration), we have already made significant improvementsтАФdigital onboarding, automated documentation, and trackable increment cycles.
Filling out a form multiple times usually stems from incomplete submission, not HR inefficiency.
Office Conditions Are Bad
WeтАЩve invested in a new workspace, and any infrastructure issue (e.g., AC installation, seating, etc.) is being addressed. We take employee health and hygiene very seriously, and multiple teams (Admin, Facilities) are working on feedback shared during this transition.
Firing Without Reason
This is categorically false. Every termination is backed by documentationтАФbe it performance issues, code of conduct violations, or contractual non-compliance. We also provide warnings and PIPs (Performance Improvement Plans) where applicable.
Dismissals are not based on someone тАЬnot liking an idea.тАЭ ThatтАЩs not how we operate.
DevOps, BA, Designers, Security = All Bad?
Attacking every tech and support team with generic accusations and insults shows more about the reviewer's mindset than our departments.


DevOps: Our deployment pipelines are containerized, CI/CD integrated, and aligned with cloud best practices.


BA Team: They define business flow, handle documentation, and are crucial in ensuring client satisfaction.


Design Team: Our work has been delivered across global clients, appreciated for both UI/UX and innovation.


Security: Awareness sessions are for user education. Real security policies, WAF rules, and code-level scans are handled internallyтАФnot on public display.


No Recognition or Reward
Recognition existsтАФand many employees have received bonuses, performance-based increments, promotions, international opportunities, and training access. But recognition doesnтАЩt mean giving in to every demand or tolerating disruptive behavior.
Final Words
We respect freedom of expression, but malicious, baseless, and exaggerated reviews damage not just company reputation but also demotivate the hardworking teams youтАЩve unfairly criticized.
We are proud of our employees, and we will not stay silent when they are misrepresented.
If you had real issues, the door to HR and senior leadership was always open. Choosing anonymous defamation over resolution is not the mark of professionalism.
We remain focused on continuous improvementтАФand on building a company where merit, respect, and accountability are the foundations of success.

post_title: Worst for software engineers. Avoid!!!!
full_review: The CEO will treat you like a free kamla. Must have to work on alternative Saturdays, but for what? nothing actually. The CEO, Fahim, doesn't even care about the developers at all. Will give you deadlines which are impossible to fulfil and will give changes on the last overview after the project is done. 8 hours of work you have to follow strictly. They will cut the time if you want to go to pee also. Indoor facility is a wonder word in Bdjobs. You will get only rong cha and 10 tk snacks; sometimes it is 5. Over time, with your hard work, everything is underrated here; else you are in a product team. Juniors and seniors must avoid this company. (The pc and chair my god! god save my eyes and butt!) Only benefits: flexible timing friendly environment Average for interns

post_title: When will the increment be good?
full_review: Pros: Work life balance is great. Benefits are decent. Cons: They'll act like they're the best while they are not Very limited chances. Have to work on legacy codes most of the times. And when in the blue hell will the increment be decent? It's a good place if you're trying for FAANG, Higher Studies, or GRE. It's a better place if you just want to have a hassle free life with the salary you're given(which is very little compared to the other large tech companies)

post_title: A Cautionary Tale from a Current SQA Engineer - Proceed with Extreme Caution
full_review: A Cautionary Tale from a Current SQA Engineer - Proceed with Extreme Caution As an SQA Engineer at Allgentech, I feel compelled to share a brutally honest account of my experience for the sake of transparency. While I joined with hope and ambition, it has become increasingly clear that this company is plagued by deep-rooted issues that make it a toxic and unstable place to work. 1. Lack of Leadership & Guidance The team lead's absence of direction has been a major hurdle. ThereтАЩs no mentorship, no structured feedback, and no clear roadmap. Junior team members are often left to fend for themselves, resulting in confusion, inefficiency, and a massive dent in morale. This isnтАЩt just mismanagementтАФitтАЩs outright neglect. 2. Job Security is Nonexistent One of the most distressing aspects of working here is the constant cloud of uncertainty. Decisions are made arbitrarily, and there's zero transparency from upper management. Several capable engineers have been let go without explanation or due process. If you're looking for a stable, growth-oriented roleтАФlook elsewhere. 3. Unacceptable Behavior from Leadership Perhaps the most disturbing issue has been the unprofessional and borderline sexually inappropriate behavior from the Principal. What makes it worse is that these actions go unchecked. The company's inaction in the face of such misconduct reflects an appalling lack of integrity and accountability. No one should feel unsafe or degraded in their workplace, and yet, that is exactly whatтАЩs happening here. In conclusion, Allgentech might offer you a job, but it wonтАЩt offer you respect, safety, or growth. For your careerтАЩs sakeтАФand mental well-beingтАФplease think twice before joining.

post_title: Review for All Generations Tech
full_review: Review for All Generations Tech: My experience working at All Generations Tech has been deeply disappointing and professionally damaging. The environment is severely mismanaged, starting with the complete lack of leadership from the team lead. There is no vision, no structure, and no real support for engineers to grow or succeed. Guidance is non-existent тАФ you're expected to figure out complex tasks entirely on your own, often with zero context or documentation, and then blamed when things go wrong. The lack of job security is another major concern. Roles and responsibilities are constantly shifting without notice, and firings happen abruptly with little to no justification. Benefits are minimal to none, and the company makes no effort to create a sustainable or motivating work culture. But most concerning of all тАФ and something that needs to be publicly addressed тАФ is the inappropriate and borderline predatory behavior exhibited by the Principal SQA Engineer. Repeated instances of uncomfortable comments, unsolicited personal inquiries, and unprofessional conduct have been tolerated and brushed under the rug. Reporting such issues is a dead end due to the lack of a proper HR structure and the culture of silence within leadership. If you value your career, mental health, and professional dignity, I strongly advise against joining this company. The red flags here are not just warning signs тАФ theyтАЩre sirens.

post_title: Extremely Toxic Environment with No Work-Life Balance тАУ Avoid at All Costs
full_review: Toxic Culture: The company fosters an extremely negative and controlling environment. ThereтАЩs no room for open communication, and employees are constantly monitored. Poor Work-Life Balance: YouтАЩre expected to work like a robot. Breaks are limited to just 15 minutes in the morning and 10 minutes in the eveningтАФbarely enough to breathe. Micromanagement & Surveillance: Screens are monitored constantly. You can't talk freely with colleagues, and collaboration feels restricted. Zero Career Growth: No matter how long you stay, thereтАЩs no real growth or learning opportunities. Senior employees often act like theyтАЩre above others and offer no support. Unqualified Leadership: CTO (Sabbir Ahmed): Offers irrelevant, AI-generated advice and lacks real technical leadership. His position appears to be a product of favoritism, not merit. COO: Comes across more like a clown than an operations leader. CEO & MD: They are the root cause of the toxic culture. They care more about headcount during visits from their Canadian boss than actual productivity or employee well-being. Project Managers: Mostly act like messengers without real decision-making power. Unprofessional HR: Some HR personnel, especially the female staff, lack basic professionalism and interpersonal skills. Fake Hiring Strategy: They hire many people when foreign visitors are in town just to show inflated numbers, then let people go afterward. Unfair Work Distribution: You'll often do the same work as senior team members but with less pay and zero recognition. Some seniors behave like they are your boss without offering help or guidance.

full_review: Bad Things 1. They always listen to the Japan side engineers and never judge which side has issue acctually. They should take this matter seriously otherwise they will lost good engineers. 2. Less flexibility. Good Things 1. Working environment is good, Opportunity to learn new technology 2. Salary issue was resolved, they give on time salary now. 3. SDLC practice is appriciated here. Other concern about recent review on this website. As a colleague who has worked closely with M******, I feel compelled to speak up after seeing the recent false and damaging claims being spread about him. These allegations are completely untrue and clearly stem from personal frustration by individuals who were let go due to serious breaches of company policyтАФincluding stealing source code, unprofessional conduct, and lack of necessary skills. I wonтАЩt mention their names here, but if anyone wants to know, I can share. In contrast, M****** has always been a committed, talented, and highly respected leader in our Engineering Department. Without his guidance and effort, the company would not have been able to grow into such a well-organized and large team. He is one of the most skilled individuals in this company. From problem-solving to management decisions, everything he contributes is thoughtful and impactful. I donтАЩt understand why some people are jealous of himтАФperhaps because he advanced his career quickly by consistently proving himself to the Japanese management. He has received multiple awards, represented the company internationally (including visits to Japan), and consistently delivers high-quality work. His efforts have been publicly recognized by our CEO Nakamura-san, as well as the Managing Director, Chairman, and other senior leaders, which speaks volumes about his integrity and contributions. I understand how easily misinformation can spread online, but as someone who has witnessed his work ethic and character firsthand, I can confidently say these accusations are baseless. Our company takes workplace conduct very seriously, and if there were ever any real concerns, they would be addressed through proper internal channelsтАФnot through anonymous and defamatory posts. LetтАЩs not allow the actions of a few disgruntled individuals to overshadow the hard work and dedication of someone who truly adds value to our organization.

Tanima Yousuf is a former employee who was officially terminated from the company for stealing source codeтАФa serious violation of company policy and industry ethics. It's unfortunate that someone like her, who was removed for such misconduct, is now attempting to tarnish the reputation of the company and a respected, high-performing leader. Anyone is welcome at any time to visit our office to check the reality. The Japanese management is not foolish to promote him three times within two years if he were not capable enough. It's shameful for individuals like her who actually destroy our national reputation in front of other nations. Throughout my time working with him, Mirajul has always maintained a professional, respectful, and inclusive attitude toward all colleagues. No one of the company will believe that he is pervert. Totally fake information. I urge readers not to be misled by baseless and vindictive claims. The facts speak for themselves, and itтАЩs unfair to let false narratives overshadow the contributions of someone who has earned their position through hard work, talent, and integrity.

post_title: Toxic and Unprofessional Work Culture
full_review: Pros: Honestly, none worth mentioning based on my experience. Cons: Toxic work environment with no supportive or collaborative culture. Employees are treated like property after hiring, not as professionals. Freshers are expected to perform like senior developers without proper guidance. Management lacks empathy and puts employees under constant pressure. No structured salary increment policy тАФ promotions and raises are unclear or nonexistent. Freshers are sometimes threatened with salary reductions after being hired. CEO has used inappropriate language (including slang) when addressing employees, creating a disrespectful atmosphere. Lack of respect in communication; feedback is often discouraging rather than constructive. Advice to Management: Treat employees with basic respect and professionalism. Create a structured growth path, maintain transparent policies, and foster a healthier, more positive work environment тАФ starting from the top.

post_title: DS! is a good place to work
full_review: DS! is a classic software company in Bangladesh with a flexible work environment. You can grow fast if you push yourself, or work comfortably at your own pace. The company has great learning resources and expert engineers, and knowledge sharing is a big part of the culture. The top three leaders are highly skilled software engineers, making the whole environment very developer-friendly. Recently, DS! introduced an engineering manager layer, so the management side is growing and improving. While there were some management gaps before, theyтАЩre being addressed now. Other facilities are being added, though snacks, lunch are a bit expensive. Salaries are always on time. Like any company, DS! has had ups and downs, but the last five years showed strong growth, and now itтАЩs in a stable phaseтАФsoon expected to grow again, InshaAllah. ItтАЩs a fresher-friendly approach and gives newcomers flexibility early on. Overall, DS! is a good place to work in the Bangladeshi tech scene

post_title: Best Company to Learn and Grow
full_review: O11yo (previously known as J00mShap3r too), is one of the finest companies in Bangladesh. I have worked for few years in the company. Their culture, learning and growth environment, quality of research and development is truly fantastic. I would not believe if anyone say negative about it, because I worked for a quality time there, and joined there with no reference from anyone from that company. They hired me from public openings. I am so glad that I worked in this company and got opportunity to work with some fantastic young people. I got a great CTO at my time, a true Tech Guru and legend. He established agile scrum with PM processes fantastically in the organization, and we learned JIRA well at his time. I got a fantastic CEO. There was another great UX Guru, who made the designs live at his time. Especially, CEO is such a talent who truly knows what he is making, and I admire him for that. I am glad that I learned a lot from the company that helped me to join my next company in a great role where I am working now. I wish all the best for the team.
