I am working as a contractual ui/ux designer for about 4 months here. Like every other companies it has its pros and cons.
Pros:

No bureaucracy. I can reach out to the top management anytime and ask for direction or assistance if needed.
Work from home and no 9-5 work culture which give a nice work life balance.
No issues with the payment so far.
The pay rate is better then many companies in bangladesh. At least for the ui/ux role.

Cons:

Very limited options to become a permanent employee.
Full remote, so it feels too casual sometimes.
This job is good as a side hustle. Meaning you have a full time job somewhere else but you want to earn extra money.

I can say it is better than many companies. It is good if you want to earn extra money beside your full time job. But if you are looking for long term option with career progress opportunities, then this is not for you.

post_title: Disappointed and burnt out
full_review: Was excited to join but quickly realized the culture is not what they advertise. ItтАЩs all politics and optics. Spent more time in justifying my work than actually doing any meaningful work. Promotion process is a nightmare тАФ it's more about who advocates for you than what you actually contribute. Manager barely knew what my team was working on and only showed up when upper management was watching. Had to deal with passive-aggressive coworkers who smiled in meetings but blocked me in code reviews. Overwhelmed with OKRs, performance trackers, and feedback cycles that felt more like surveillance than support. The тАЬperksтАЭ are just shiny distractions to keep you at the office longer тАФ free food isnтАЩt worth the mental toll. Burnt out within a year. Took me months after quitting to feel normal again.

post_title: How NOT to foster software engineers 101
full_review: My least favorite professional experience in life was at Bdtask as a fresh graduate. They objectively dangle delicious objectives leading to delirium but then you get seated in a room that persistently smells like poo owing to the poorly ventilated toilets less than 20 feet from the room where the seat the freshers and greenhorns. The dining room, also next to the toilets, often gets flooded with poo poo water, and while it sounds super childish and unrealistic, its 100% true and I hold a severe grudge against them for how they held me hostage for 6 months. The details, however, can not be divulged as it would give away my identity and endanger what little career I have left. The seniors act like insufferable little know-it-alls, closed off to any sort of mentoring but always open to pick a fight. Management treats employees like garment workers, requiring employees to clock out even if they leave the workstation for 5 minutes. I understand that company time is company time, but the company doesn't get to disguise a 9 hour work day into 10 hours by omitting lunch, prayers and miscellanous breaks. They say prayer breaks would be xenophobic (!) and lunch breaks are nonsensical because no two peope have lunch at the same time. So yeah that's that. 0/10, would never recommend it/

post_title: Dishonest, Cheap, Thief, Did not pay the due allowance
full_review: My interaction with them was through an FTFL (Fast track future leaders) program, funded by World Bank. It was a paid┬а training program on cutting edge technologies. They somehow managed to get this project (with potential political connection back then). They gave a lot less training allowance then was alloted to each trainee, Did not use the budget alloted to buy equipments, Instead bought a very few cheap embedded devices, Did not arrange the afternoon snack that was alloted in budget, Did not pay full amount for all the months even (3 months allowance was supposed to be provided to us. Only 2 month allowance was given to some of the trainees. For other they used excuse like did not attend enough classes). All-in-all, they were just in dhanda to steal from wherever they could. Besides, the CEO misinformed and lied (vugichugi bujh) to us that it is a join venture, and we are kind of their employee, and he her sister (who also worked there) treated us with rather harsh attitude.

post_title: Political enviroment
full_review: Salaries are significantly below industry standards. Extremely long working hours (often 14тАУ15 hours/day), with minimal respect for personal time. Employees are expected to work during major life events (e.g., weddings, emergencies), including holidays like Eid. There is no true work-life balance; employees must wait for higher-ups to leave even after completing daily hours. Internal politics dominate decisions, limiting merit-based growth. Technical skills are undervaluedтАФmanagement often claims that only 20% of growth is based on skills, and 80% on "communication" (a proxy for favoritism). Favoritism and gender bias are common in promotions and rewards. Employees focusing on technical excellence are often overlooked in favor of those who engage in personal networking. Contributions by employees are frequently unrecognized, with higher-ups taking credit. Mistakes due to vague instructions are blamed on juniors. Employees are at times told to log work under someone else's account, hiding their contributions. Opportunities for growth, skill development, or exposure to new technologies are severely limited. Conversations and communications are heavily monitored. Cross-team collaboration is discouraged. Trust and autonomy are lacking, creating a suffocating work atmosphere. Employees are pressured to attend expensive company trips at their own expense. Non-participation is unofficially frowned upon and seen as career-damaging. Tasks are often beyond job descriptions and pay grades, with no compensation or recognition. Work-from-home flexibility is advertised but reserved for management. Overtime and weekend work are common and unpaid, despite earlier promises of compensatory leave. HR plays a disproportionately large role in technical decisions and employee management. Initiatives to learn or grow are suppressed. Developers are often stuck with repetitive tasks with no exposure to modern tools or frameworks. The environment is not developer-friendly; developers are undervalued compared to non-technical staff. The quality of product delivery is not a major concern. The workload resembles a garments factory's more than a professional tech company. Management practices are inefficient, chaotic, and demotivating. Hard work goes unappreciated.

post_title: UK Based Mula Business
full_review: I have a long career journey. Throughout this journey, I have faced many ups and downs. When I joined this UK-based company, which is the parent company of Doctime (people don't recognize Media365 Limited, so they mention Doctime in job posts), I had a shocking experience just after joining! I saw our CEO come from the UK and already fire more than 10 people тАФ and some were in the queue. Our CEO then arranged a meeting and described this situation as part of a business failure. He mentioned the word "cost cutting" around 100 times. So, instead of focusing on growth, this company continuously thrived on cost cutting and limiting budgets. One of my junior colleagues who joined before me had his probation period extended. Another colleague didnтАЩt get the salary hike that was promised before joining. They set nearly impossible deadlines, assigned irrelevant tasks that didnтАЩt align with oneтАЩs responsibilities, and gave no appreciation for hard work тАФ a very common scenario here. Our Project Manager / VP of Engineering operates the entire department from the UK. He doesnтАЩt have any idea about the complexity of any particular task. The only thing that matters to him is when the task will be finished. He also doesnтАЩt know the difference between complex and easy tasks тАФ and believes no task should take more than 2-3 days. Sometimes, it seems he is completely a non-tech guy running the entire engineering department! These are the things I have experienced here. It has some positive sides too тАФ unlimited coffee, snacks (cookies), healthy food for lunch (partially subsidized), evening snacks, a smiley tech lead (donтАЩt know whatтАЩs behind that smile, don't trust him, don't share your personal thoughts or plans with him, be very careful of him), football matches, annual tour, etc. Note: They donтАЩt pay your bonus during the notice period, even if you are eligible after serving more than one year.

post_title: Won't hire after internship
full_review: I, along with 14 others, attended their internship program last year. They had promised to hire at least 2тАУ3 people as full-time employees after the internship. However, they didn't hire a single person, despite our good performance. Later, we found out that they had used us to present a larger workforce to potential clients for a project that ultimately didnтАЩt materialize. As a result, they rejected all of us for full-time positions.

comments.comment_text: Soo true.. After the internship program, they will give you a certificate, that's all. They don't even tell the reasons.

post_title: Irregular Salary, No Job Security, and No Future Growth
full_review: NE> The salary disbursement is extremely irregular and unreliable. Employees often receive only 30-40% of their monthly salaries in partial installments spread across two or three settlements. In some cases, the company fails to pay the remaining due even after several months. Worse still, there have been instances where employees did not receive their pending dues after resigning, reflecting a serious lack of ethics and professionalism. There is no job security, no clear career path, and no supportive work culture. Overall, the environment is unstable and demotivating. I would not recommend this company to anyone looking for a serious and respectful career opportunity.

post_title: Best place to work if you're a NEET with zero talent
full_review: Pros Unlimited caffeine and food. Sports room and a Play room with a PS5, perfect for decompressing after a hard day of eating, shitting, and editing JSON files. Colleagues are ( mostly ) friendly. Engineering? Optional. Most of the work involves tweaking JSONs until something тАЬjust works.тАЭ If youтАЩre terrified of never making it in tech, getting in here is like securing permanent employment for life. ThereтАЩs this curious pattern where ex-employees leave, suddenly turn into brilliant engineers, and start making serious money elsewhere. Orbitax doesnтАЩt exactly nurture talent; it just injects enough frustration to push people to go above and beyond, level up, and escape this charming little utopia. Multiple annual trips, both local and international (only poor SEA countries). This serves as an effective distraction from the creeping realization that you're slowly settling into a life of overwork and quiet mediocrity. Cons Depending on your team lead, you may need to do some light glazing (details redacted). The codebase was designed by someone read Uncle Bob once and couldn't find a better outlet to unleash his newfound passion for over-engineering. Want to add a simple button? Sorry, youтАЩll need to navigate the CoreтДв library, a radioactive wasteland of Lovecraftian horror. ( Pro Tip: Aim to position yourself in the golden mean within the company. Not bad enough to get blamed for everything, but not good enough to be trusted with touching this monstrosity of an abstraction layer). Weekend work does happen occasionally (but they let you sleep it off later with a compensatory day off).

full_review: This is a good company for those people who want to learn new things and work with dynamic project. This is a fully remote position and it gives opportunity to stay with your family. This is blessing for me. Also gives all the government government holidays. Maximum time you don't need to work after office hour.┬а During project deadline sometime need to work after office hour. post_title: There is no future for the company or its employees.
full_review: The boss of this company is extremely delusional. He favors people who are good at flattery rather than those with real skills. There is no clear visionтАФemployees are simply expected to implement his unrealistic ideas. Internal politics are rampant. In every department, the team leads are often ineffective but maintain their positions by flattering upper management. One of the worst situations is in the tech team, which is heavily politicized. The tech team lead there is extremely toxicтАФhe actively suppresses the growth of other team members and is deeply involved in office politics.

post_title: Inhumane Management Practices at Therap
full_review: The current management at Therap has been treating employees unfairly. Despite Buddha Purnima falling on Sunday, 11th May тАФ a recognized public holiday тАФ the office will remain open without any form of compensation. A similar situation occurred during the recent Eid holidays. Although the government declared April 3rd as an Eid holiday and our director initially stated in the company workspace that we would observe it, the plan was later changed. Instead, we were informally told to work from home, likely to avoid leaving a digital record. When the CEO and COO visited Bangladesh, work hours were extended by an hour, and some employees were even required to come in on Fridays and Saturdays, again without any compensation for the extra hours. Lately, there have also been delays in salary disbursement.

post_title: Needs Serious Organizational Reform тАУ Not Recommended for Developers
full_review: The company lacks stability for tech professionals. During any investment challenges, the development team often faces abrupt downsizing, which severely impacts morale and continuity. Instead of offering increments or permanent roles to existing developers, the company tends to replace long-term employees with new hires тАФ a pattern observed specifically in the development department. Some senior individuals from departments such as Marketing, Product, and HR exhibit behavior as if they own the organization. Their involvement in favoritism, manipulation, and internal politics contributes significantly to a toxic work environment. Leadership in the backend team has been a major concern. A particular senior developer previously dismissed from Shuttle, Hishabee, and Codemoly has negatively impacted the teamтАЩs productivity and culture before eventually being let go. Basic workplace facilities such as lunch, snacks, prayer space, or any form of recreation are unavailable, which is disappointing in a professional environment. While the development team often delivers under tight deadlines and contributes to successful releases, recognition is disproportionately given to Sales and Customer Support. Developers remain largely unacknowledged for their hard work. Additional concerns include unrealistic deadlines, inconsistent salary increments, and the formation of team leader cliques that stifle growth and fairness.

post_title: Poorest and unprofessional management
full_review: boss in Bangladesh is very business oriented, he doesn't bother to replace employees even if they are sick just to run his business! one of our colleagues got pregnant and he didn't give her paid leave! Rather asked her to join when her baby was 2 months old just because she asked for eid bonus and eid month salary. She was even asked to join part time with the excuse of not being able to manage work full time because she has a baby to take care of! This led that colleague to resign from her position. Silver lining is this company disburse salary within the 28th of the month, they have PF facilities, gratuity, fully subsidised lunch and snacking.

He still denied and for that I decided to rejoin within less than 2 months of post partum and told him that. He approved that but again he offered me part time work with the excuse "tmr akhn career er cheye beshi focus kora dorkar family and baby k so i don't think you can work full time" this basically convinced me to look for new jobs. I knocked him 2 days prior to my rejoin date and told that i don't wanna resume because I already got another offer and a very good one! At that time he tried in many ways to change my decision but i denied and said i don't wanna work anymore right back then. Yes I lied but I think that was an obvious situation. I again requested him for the eid bonus (before taking the resignation decision) atleast but he was like "tumi ki ei time e kaj korso j bonus paba? rozar eid er ta tou paisoi" I was speechless after hearing that because in my little knowledge I didn't know what was the bonus eligibilty (though as per comapny handbook any employee would be eligible for eid bonuses after 1 year of joining)┬аanyways, i decided to quit and in the meantime i had gone to the office several times and NGL office did gift my newborn some stuff and I am thankful for that.┬аnow coming to the 2nd comment, thank you whoever wrote on behalf of me- just a correction, I think you have written just what management told you. There was nothing to decide later from them and I didn't ask for immideate leave- I handed over all the responsibilites as well so there should not be any question on that. We were in WFH that time as it was Ramadan and I told my boss that I might need some time off as I got to know the preganancy late and I needed to undergone various tests and medical attentions as those were the last crutial situations and many times informed him that I will go on leave from April 1. Yes definitely my ex boss called me and my husband several times for me and my baby's update.┬аI am just writing the overall facts what I have faced so my sincere apology for these long post.┬аbefore conclude, just want to say one thing, my ex boss just made me dumb and less confident by saying "tumi tou amake lojjay fele dila, tmk diye hocche na and stuff like this" for very minor mistkaes and subconsciously that hit my mind so bad that after joining in my new job I was so so so determined to validate my capabilty and ALHAMDULILLAH i have done that. Just a sincere request to the management, PLEASE DO NOT GIVE ANY FALSE HOPE TO EMPLOYEES AND PLEASE DO NOT SAY SUCH THINGS TO EMPLOYEES ON WHICH THEY FEEL DUMB. I don't have any complaints about be data solutions ltd, I do have very few but positive memories there. But yes I am so happy that i decided to quit that place. I have huge workload right now and so many responsibilites but atleast I have got my mental peace and job satisfaction back.┬а

Just being honest:
The employee in question did not inform management about her pregnancy until she was seven months along. In fact, none of the team members were aware of her condition. When she finally disclosed the news, she also requested immediate maternity leave. At that point, she was actively involved in several client projects, and management had to urgently begin searching for a replacement тАФ which wasnтАЩt easy.
Rather than being honest with her, management made vague, misleading promises тАФ telling her to go on leave and that they would тАЬdecide later.тАЭ This lack of transparency created false hope. Now that she's ready to return, management is simply brushing her off, saying theyтАЩve already hired a replacement and wonтАЩt тАЬwaste moneyтАЭ on her. ItтАЩs a disappointing and unprofessional from management, how they handle this situation.┬а

post_title: Something is Wrong - Nobody Knows What or Pretends They Don't Know
full_review: Being a Marketer in a Dev-Centric Company Hurts You market a buggy product, bring in sales, then get blamed when refunds come in. Low retention? Your fault. Poor conversion? Also you. Outdated UI, broken features, unhappy users тАФ all somehow on marketing. But hereтАЩs the truth: the devs arenтАЩt to blame either. TheyтАЩre overworked and understaffed. ItтАЩs not laziness, itтАЩs overload. TheyтАЩre trying to keep up, just like you are. Meanwhile, the product suffers. User feedback gets ignored. And the blame game never stops. Being a marketer here feels like pulling a broken cart uphill. If we stop pointing fingers and start building together, we can fix this. Still hopeful. Still here.

post_title: Overall, my experience at weDevs has been very positive.
full_review: Friendly Work Environment : The work culture at weDevs is incredibly supportive and feels like a family. Everyone is welcoming and always ready to help. Career Growth Opportunities : IтАЩve had great opportunities to learn and grow professionally here. ThereтАЩs always something new to pick up, and the company supports that. Great Benefits : The perks are amazingтАФfree food, unlimited snacks, lunch allowances, and timely bonuses. These are some of the highlights. Supportive Management : Management is approachable and encourages collaboration. IтАЩve found them to be very helpful in navigating challenges. Work-Life Balance : Flexible hours and a reasonable workload make it easier to maintain a healthy balance between work and personal life. High Job Satisfaction : IтАЩm not alone in thisтАФmost people here are satisfied with their work and the environment. Modern Workplace : The office is comfortable, with amenities like a gaming room, which makes the environment even more engaging and enjoyable. Slow Administrative Processes : One of the challenges IтАЩve noticed is the delays in HR or administrative tasks. It can be frustrating at times. Mid-Management Issues : There are some inefficiencies with mid-level management. Sometimes things can feel unclear, and that causes delays or confusion. Limited Ownership for Juniors : As a junior, I sometimes feel like IтАЩm limited in taking on bigger responsibilities. ThereтАЩs a bit of a glass ceiling when it comes to leadership roles.

post_title: Finally Found a Team That Cares
full_review: Working at Friends Corp has been a refreshing and rewarding experience for me in a senior position. From day one, IтАЩve felt genuinely valued not just for my skills but also as a person. This is something I truly missed in one of my previous companies. The team culture is warm and supportive, and thereтАЩs always someone ready to help or simply listen when needed. ItтАЩs not just about finishing tasks, itтАЩs about growing together. One thing I really appreciate is the freedom to share ideas and try out new approaches. Mistakes are treated as part of the learning journey, not something to fear. That kind of mindset builds confidence and encourages creativity. Working with people from Japan and other parts of the world has also been a great experience. It has helped me learn a lot and grow both professionally and personally. In short, Friends Corp doesnтАЩt just feel like a workplace. It feels like a place where IтАЩm motivated to do my best every day while being part of a respectful and inspiring team.

post_title: Honest Review of the Company
full_review: The company severely lacks a professional work culture. The management is often preoccupied with issues from their other ventures, leaving little to no attention for employee development or organizational improvement. Employees are frequently overworked and undervalued, with treatment that can feel exploitative. One of the most concerning practices is that, upon resignation, the company withholds essential documents like experience certificates and No Objection Certificates (NOCs), which can seriously affect future employment opportunities. There is no structured environment for learning, career growth, or mentorship. The organizational structure is extremely weak, with no clear processes or support systems in place. Despite these serious issues, the company appears to be fabricating positive reviews to mislead potential hires, especially fresh graduates. I strongly advise job seekers, particularly those starting their careers, to exercise caution before considering this company.

post_title: Software engineer kamla
full_review: With all the buzz the city bank creates with trendy corpo talks, the city bank IT division is a shit show where they will tell you they have great expectations from you and if you are able to deliver them the rewards are endless. But this just a "mula" they hang in front of you and you are nothing but kamla to them. But this kamla not only have to deliver but have to deliver them with dress code and if by any chance you take a day or two sick leave all your deliveries will become worthless. So if you want to become stressed kamla on the verge of collapse, please join the wonderful world of City Bank IT division. I wish someone told me this before i joined this shithole and burned my peace of mind. The corporate politics are rampant, this no place for engineers to be in. This placed forced me to forget all my engineering practices and just deliver anything at any cost.

post_title: Could Have been the the Best in BD, Ended up being Average because of poor Decisions
full_review: Strong Focus on Kubernetes and Cloud-Native Technologies Appscode operates deeply within the Kubernetes and cloud-native ecosystem, providing engineers the opportunity to work with cutting-edge and highly sought-after technologies. For developers passionate about infrastructure, automation, and distributed systems, this is a major advantage. Open Core Projects with Community Impact The company maintains open core projects that are tightly integrated with the Kubernetes ecosystem. This allows engineers to contribute to widely adopted tools, build a strong public portfolio, and gain recognition within the open-source community. Dedicated Time for Research and Development (R&D) Engineers are encouraged to spend time on R&D, often engaging with complex technical challenges such as scalability, distributed systems, and automation. This fosters deep technical growth and intellectual stimulation. Accelerated Learning and Growth Opportunities Due to the nature of the work and the technology stack, team members gain significant hands-on experience and exposure in a relatively short period. There's good number of stable and prominent clients like Nokia, Microsoft, GreenHouse etc. Collaborative, Developer-Friendly Environment The office culture, largely shaped and maintained by the employees themselves, is supportive and collaborative. The company has a strong engineering-focused culture, with many team members coming from competitive programming backgrounds. This shared technical mindset fosters mutual understanding and helps new hires adapt quickly. Competitive Local Compensation Salaries are well-aligned with the local market, and payments are reliably made on time. Risk of Burnout The high-paced nature of the work and the constant learning curve can lead to burnout if not properly managed by both individuals and leadership. Limited Project Rotation Engineers often remain on the same project for extended periods. While this can deepen expertise, it can also lead to stagnation or frustration, especially when moving on to a very similar project afterward. Understaffed Office Management The HR and administrative departments are relatively small and under-resourced, which can lead to miscommunication or poorly handled internal matters. Limited Recreation and Wellness Facilities There are currently insufficient provisions for physical activities, team-building events, or relaxation spaces. As the company scales, this gap is becoming more apparent and increasingly necessary to address. Inconsistent Performance Review Process Underperformance is not always addressed in a timely or constructive manner. Some employees receive inadequate feedback or support, which can lead to abrupt terminations or demoralization. Top-Down Leadership Approach Leadership often prioritizes their own strategic vision over team feedback. This can create a disconnect between management and employees and reduce the sense of inclusivity and ownership within the team. Lack of Mutual Commitment in Employment New hires are frequently expected to commit for the long term, but the organization does not always reciprocate this commitment. The dismissal of experienced team members has contributed to a higher-than-average turnover rate and organizational instability. Demotivating Work Culture Inconsistent managerial support and the absence of a strong, cohesive office culture can lead to disengagement and reduced morale across the team. Short Career Progression Trajectory There is limited visibility into long-term career paths within the company. Most engineers tend to leave within 2тАУ3 years, often due to a lack of professional growth opportunities. Actively collect and review employee feedbackтАФboth current and formerтАФto identify areas for organizational improvement. Reassess company policies around work-life balance, employee well-being, leave structure, and office environment to better align with company growth and employee needs. Invest in clear career development frameworks and employee retention strategies to support long-term growth and reduce attrition. Foster a more inclusive and transparent leadership culture where feedback from all levels is considered and valued.

post_title: BRAC IT тАУ A Playground for Power, Favoritism, and Toxic Culture
full_review: These counter-statements show how BRAC IT current management handle feedback, reflecting the mindset of the CEO, the Head of Delivery and Governance, the CTO, and the Head of Employee Experience, QA, and Admin. the CEO and HoD Delivery and Governance often silence employees through direct or indirect threats of termination, creating a culture where speaking up feels risky. BRAC IT has relied heavily on BRAC as its main client for years. ItтАЩs not competitors damaging your reputation тАУ itтАЩs your own biased practices, favoritism, and internal power struggles. YouтАЩve created a culture that values loyalty over merit, encouraging small, exclusive groups, free mixing, unprofessional behavior, and ignoring genuine concerns. Instead of building a professional work environment, the focus has shifted to normalizing behaviors like drinking, promoting free mixing, party-like culture, and surrounding yourself with people who support your decisions, right or wrong, rather than those who are genuinely skilled. The CEO often uses his connections with senior figures of BRAC to avoid accountability, mentioning these links to suppress dissent. The Head of Delivery and Governance, despite having limited leadership skills, was hired to a senior role, largely due to his loyalty to the current acting CEO and personal connections. His past behavior, including reported arrogance and unprofessional conduct, has created a toxic work environment where even female colleagues hesitate to speak up, fearing job insecurity. He reportedly secured his position through personal influence rather than merit, leveraging his network to gain power. Meanwhile, loyal but unskilled hires are brought in to support the personal agendas of the leadership, creating a culture where real talent is sidelined, and genuine employees are overburdened, handling both their own work and the work of these favored but less competent colleagues. This toxic culture is eroding the companyтАЩs long-term reputation, making it a place for chilling and enjoyment rather than real work and growth.

post_title: Leaders who made the company a living HELL
full_review: Port0n1cs was once regarded as a benchmark for company culture and developer experience in Bangladesh. It attracted top talent and fostered an environment where innovation and collaboration thrived. Unfortunately, that chapter seems to have come to a close. In recent times, the departure of visionary leaders has left the company in the hands of individuals who appear to lack both the technical depth and emotional intelligence necessary to lead. The current leadership seems more concerned with control than with growthтАФboth their own and their teamтАЩs. Rather than empowering developers, they push a culture of overwork, where 12тАУ18 hour days for months on end are considered the norm. Refusing to comply with these unrealistic demands can quickly lead to one being labeled a тАЬlow performer.тАЭ Perhaps most concerning is the toxic internal politics. Developers are subtly (and at times directly) encouraged to undermine their seniorsтАФnot based on merit or professionalism, but because those seniors pose a perceived threat to insecure leadership. Only exception is the QA Lead , who is the OG member of Portonics and still carries the old essence of the company While the base salary structure remains competitive and annual increments are decent, the bonus system is poorly thought out and fails to reflect the contributions or sacrifices of the team. Developers who value integrity, a healthy work-life balance, and a culture of mutual respect may want to think twice before committing to Portonics in its current state. Talented individuals have already begun to move onтАФand unless significant changes are made, that trend is likely to continue. I was able to leave the company before it became unbearable. Can't say the same for my colleagues, who are still suffering . If you are Planing to join here, don't, trust me . If you are appearing for the interview, if your skill set is better than the leader, you will be rejected. If your skill is moderate and you are submissive, you will be surely selected

post_title: Worst HR and CEO you can ever get
full_review: I was their employee for more than 1 year, and all the time HRтАЩs self-proclaimed responsibility was coming to the office late, sitting with the CEO for the majority of her time, and interfering with the marketing team on each activity as that's the only place where she can put her little knowledge exaggeratly. Whereas the CEO is known as the head of the company but everything is operated with HR's instructions. The whole social media content is just for showing off, aside from that, the company always prioritizes employees who can put butter on the HR and CEO, not with their qualities. So, if you want to grow in your career, avoid them.

post_title: Toxic Environment, Puppet Leadership & Career Destroyer
full_review: Pros: On-time salary There were some amazing, talented teammates тАФ but sadly, most of them have already left due to the toxic environment Cons: Misleading leadership : The CEO celebrates growth all year but suddenly claims losses right before appraisals. ItтАЩs a pattern to deny employees fair raises. Frequent layoffs : No job security. Ex-CTO damaged the team culture : His decisions caused major dysfunction, and instead of accountability, it led to mass resignations and layoffs Now run by unqualified puppets : Many current leaders in key positions have no experience in other tech companies. No learning or growth : With poor leadership and no direction, you will not gain meaningful experience here. ItтАЩs a dead end for any serious tech professional. Engineers treated like factory workers : No respect for skill, no voice in decision-making. Even basic office supplies (like tea/coffee) are rationed to save money тАФ a sign of how little the company values its people. Bottom Line: Truck Lagbe is not a place for growth, innovation, or respect. ItтАЩs a place where good people burn out, careers stall, and toxic politics win. Avoid if you care about your future.

post_title: Egotistic and spineless: a combination for imminent disaster
full_review: Port0n1cs had a good reputation in the industry as having a good work culture and a tenacity to promote quality. These are the reason why I joined the company initially. This perception, when met with reality, was shattered as the company has fallen too far from grace. I didn't see any of the perceived qualities in my stay there. What I saw though was promotion of clueless individuals to leadership, long term employees being shunned and discarded like baby diapers (takes all the poop but not valued after use) and worst of all a tech leadership so spineless that the only commitment they care about is to please their egotistical leader. The only thing they can defend is their undying will to please the higher up, even if it means to disregard the suggestion of the team for completely irrational reasons. All of this is a result of an organizational leadership which is split between two individuals whose methods cannot be any different than each other. One is a methodical and strategic leader with a penchant for overseeing every aspect to the finish line, while the other is an individual who cannot do no wrong. Any and everything that he does is deemed as the best and the employees are just hindering his brilliance. Useless "team building" session of self gloating is deemed as "motivational" for the team from his eyes, while the rest of the team feels it as a waste of time. Overall majority of the departments are led by individuals who cannot be further from being qualified. The only criteria of being qualified is being favored by the man in charge. Honestly, the company can be so much better if they just figure out their issues instead of staying in denial and claiming supremacy and also make sure that qualified individuals are leading the departments instead of suck ups and loyalists. We all know how that helped BAL on the long run. Do not recommend this company, even to my enemies. And for those looking for a good work culture, look somewhere else or check if they have actually done something to make things better, instead of claiming it.

post_title: Office politics at it's max
full_review: You may heard all the golden glorified stories about this company but not it's a total mess. The company owners are busy in foreign travels and their "islamic kaj karbars". Meanwhile, the office became a playground of multi group politics. The whole company now runs by the hr and accounts people, and they dnt hesitate a bit to show this. If u talk to them for ur own need they will through some made up rules and dismis u right there. post_title: A company full of corrupted departments
full_review: I joined this company over 2 years ago. Here's my experience. Pros: 1. Timely salary. 2. You can learn skills for your own personal growth. ThatтАЩs it. Now letтАЩs talk about the consтАФwhich honestly feel endless. 1. Managers: Completely unqualified and unprofessional. They donтАЩt know what theyтАЩre doing. Every developer knows how outdated their mindset is. Most of them canтАЩt even keep up with basic trends in tech. Calling them managers is an insult to the word. 2. The management: Another clown show. No professionalism, no skill, just mood swings and yelling over petty issues. One of them randomly loses his temper like a toddler denied candy. To be fair, the CTO is a decent human being personallyтАФbut as a CTO? Clueless. 3. THE SQA DEPARTMENT (yes, this deserves all caps): The most corrupted department in this entire company. A whole floor dedicated to this circus. Most of them joined with their faceтАФnot their brain or skills. Some donтАЩt even know what automation is, let alone how to do it. IтАЩve seen peopleтАФespecially the cutiesтАФgetting in and climbing up just by being cute. SQA headтАЩs hiring policy? тАЬNo skills required, just be pretty.тАЭ And yes, IтАЩve seen the SQA head and his favorites going office together in rickshaw like some 90s love story. This entire floor is a joke. Over 50 SQAs and barely a handful actually know what software is. 4. IT Department: These guys think theyтАЩre hot stuff. Reality? TheyтАЩd be better off fixing routers in alleys or working in a local computer shop. Arrogant, disrespectful, and skill-less. If being rude was a skill, theyтАЩd be CTO by now. 5. HR Department: LetтАЩs not even start. TheyтАЩll ask you to submit the same document 5-6 times and still тАЬloseтАЭ it. Zero professionalism, no proper process, delay everythingтАФespecially increments. Recruitment? Random. Accountant acts like heтАЩs working at the Prime MinisterтАЩs Office. Pure garbage behavior. 6. DevOps: DevOps? More like тАЬLaptop Dada.тАЭ TheyтАЩre stuck in the 90s and scared of anything new. Every new tech = тАЬsecurity issue,тАЭ тАЬhigh bill,тАЭ тАЬnot needed.тАЭ Bro, if you guys are DevOps, then I can be the AWS CEO. I doubt the CDO even studied in this fieldтАФdoubt he even knows any new tech. There is a software architect I know in this company he actually knows nothing. His teammates researches and he tells management like he researched everything. But in reality he knows nothing just chapabaj. Skilled people = neglected. If youтАЩre actually good, forget about recognition. YouтАЩll get 10k yearly increment and a pat on the back if youтАЩre lucky. But if youтАЩre good at shoe lickingтАФcongrats, skyтАЩs the limit. No skills? No problem. Just be a loud тАЬyes manтАЭ and youтАЩll rise faster than inflation. IтАЩve seen senior software engineers who donтАЩt even deserve a trainee title. There are some genuinely talented devs here, and only because of them this company hasnтАЩt completely collapsed yet.

We appreciate all feedback,positive or critical. As it helps us identify areas of improvement. However, when feedback turns into personal attacks, baseless allegations, and generalizations that are far removed from reality, we feel the need to respond clearly, factually, and respectfully to uphold the integrity of our teams and the company as a whole.
Let us address the claims raised:
Management & Leadership:┬аOur managers are selected through a rigorous evaluation process that includes not only technical proficiency but also leadership potential, experience, and the ability to guide diverse teams. Claiming that every manager is тАЬunqualifiedтАЭ or тАЬcluelessтАЭ is not only factually incorrect but also deeply disrespectful to professionals who consistently work hard to ensure timely delivery, client satisfaction, and employee support.
We agree that not all leadership styles fit everyone, but we also encourage open-door communication. If someone had genuine concerns, they were always welcome to escalate them through proper channels.
SQA Department:┬аWe strongly object to the personal and sexist remarks directed at our SQA professionals. Hiring based on appearance is a serious and unfounded accusation. Our SQA team includes ISTQB-certified engineers, automation testers, and experienced professionals who have delivered on enterprise-grade projects.
Disrespectful and discriminatory language towards a specific departmentтАФespecially targeted at individuals based on gender or appearanceтАФis not criticism. ItтАЩs harassment. And we do not tolerate or entertain such behavior in our culture.
IT & DevOps:┬аOur IT and DevOps teams maintain the backbone of company operations. They work across challenging scenariosтАФfrom security compliance to cloud cost optimization and infrastructure scaling. Their cautious approach is a result of experience, not incompetence. Every tool or technology introduced is evaluated based on security, cost, and long-term viability.
We promote innovationтАФbut not at the cost of stability. This balance is intentional and necessary.
HR & Recruitment:┬аOur HR processes are ISO-audited and follow proper documentation protocols. If documents were re-requested, it was likely due to improper submission or verification compliance.
Recruitment is based on structured interviews, technical assessments, and behavior-based evaluationтАФnot favoritism or randomness. Personal attacks on our HR, finance, or admin staff reflect more on the individual making such claims than on the departments themselves.
Recognition & Compensation:┬аWe believe in fair and performance-based growth. Every increment and promotion goes through a review process. Recognition is not limited to vocal or тАЬvisibleтАЭ employeesтАФmany behind-the-scenes contributors are regularly rewarded.
However, expecting rapid promotions without aligning with organizational standards, behavior, or collaborative culture is unrealistic. We value team players, not lone rangers who disregard structure or process.
To Conclude,┬аWe understand that not every workplace is the right fit for every person. If youтАЩve moved onтАФwe sincerely wish you all the best. But if someone chooses to burn bridges through public defamation, slander, and disrespectful language, it reveals more about their professionalism than ours.
We remain committed to creating a respectful, merit-based, and inclusive environment for allтАФregardless of department, designation, or background.
For anyone currently struggling or having unresolved concerns, we encourage you to approach our HR team directly. Constructive voices are always welcome. Anonymous hostility is not.

post_title: A Message from BRAC University Students for Management
full_review: As students of BRAC University, we fully understand and resonate with the concerns raised by company employees regarding internal issues. However, we also feel itтАЩs important to share our own experiences, particularly with the BRACU Connect platform (formerly USIS), which has consistently caused significant difficulties during semester advising. Despite repeated feedback from students, 8RAC IT has often disabled their official Facebook page, limiting open dialogue. While the organization frequently emphasizes its commitment to transparency, there has been little to no clear communication or accountability regarding these recurring issues. Unfortunately, it often feels like students bear the brunt of this lack of responsiveness. From our perspective, the collaboration between BRAC University and 8RAC IT reflects a system where student concerns are frequently overlooked.

post_title: From Potential to Pause: A Reflection
full_review: Not every company gets the chance to shape an industry. This one did. It had the right people, the right momentum, and a product that mattered. For a while, it felt like the sky was the limit. You could see the alignment between purpose and performance. It was exciting to be part of something that was clearly on the rise. But somewhere along the way, the clarity faded. Strategic decisions began to feel disconnected from reality. Senior roles were created without clear purpose, salaries ballooned in strange places, and the culture of merit quietly eroded. It became harder to see the logic behind who was being empowered and why. Today, growth has slowed, and morale seems to be chasing memories of better days. Upper management appears to be in search of answers, while the root causes- often sitting in plain sight - remain unaddressed. There's a hesitance to confront the real issues, especially around a mid management that no longer adds meaningful value. To be fair, the company still provides well. Benefits, flexibility, and a baseline of respect remain. And thatтАЩs not nothing. ThereтАЩs a legacy here that many still hold affection for.

post_title: Haters Gonna Hate
full_review: It's surprisingтАФand honestly disappointingтАФto see misleading and exaggerated statements about our open environment culture at Vivasoft. As someone who loves coming to work every day, I can confidently say this company feels like home to many of us. Yes, our culture is vibrant and fast-paced, but that's precisely what fuels our creativity and productivity. Contrary to what was depicted, our teamsтАФfrom management to internsтАФare filled with passionate individuals who enthusiastically collaborate, share ideas freely, and support each other professionally and personally. We prioritize openness, respect, and innovation. There's a reason we have one of the most motivated and happy teams in the industry. Our workspace promotes openness and collaboration, encouraging everyone to engage proactively. Instead of focusing on superficial judgments, we've built an inclusive environment that brings out the best in everyone. Anyone who's genuinely experienced our culture knows how supportive and uplifting our colleagues and leadership truly are. Additionally, if someone is genuinely unhappy, it's puzzling why they would choose to stay for 5-6 years. Nobody is forced or bound by a contract to remain here against their will. Our doors have always been open for those who align with our values and seek fulfillment. Let's celebrate what makes Vivasoft special: our unique blend of enthusiasm, innovation, and genuine camaraderie. It's the authentic joy of working here that keeps us moving forwardтАФand anyone here would readily confirm this. #VivasoftCulture #TeamSpirit #LoveWhereYourWork #IfYouDontThenByeBye

post_title: Great Environment and People.
full_review: Exabyting is a lesser known name but they are trying to turn that around. The management and people here are very welcoming and friendly. The CEO claims to be very transparent about company decisions and so far I have personally not seen any incident where that was not upheld. Upper management also upholds this value. Good environment for learning as trainees get time to focus on leetcode and system design. Only concern would be that their main source of revenue is staff augmentation to a leading MFS company but they are working on bringing in more projects and partners. Being a smaller company it still has some things to figure out but I trust they will try their best.

post_title: 8JIT Academy is a scam
full_review: While starting their 4-month long unpaid training period, they'll tell you about 50% of trainees are assured of permanent job, based on performance. When you finish it, you'll realize what a scam it has always been! Because their evaluation is not fair at all. They will favor anyone they wish, not based on merit or expertise. In short, you'll lose 4 valuable months from your life. They say they'll provide certificate after finishing it but in reality they actually don't. WhatтАЩs more ridiculous is, they have a history of offering permanent job verbally & revert it on the same/next day. If you don't believe me, you can ask their former trainees. The best decision I've taken was to leave it before finishing, thanks to their toxic rules.

comments.comment_text: I think it's partially true. I am from Academy YSD B2, and we didn't see any issues with the training and hiring process. They mentioned everything in the contract, I think you didn't go through that well. HR and Academy informed us about everything in detail, the way you are saying that's not true brother/sister. And obviously they need to be more professional in dealing with trainees, we found an Intern of the Academy acted like a Director in our time, whatever!They hired more than 50% of our batch as they promised to hire 50%. And I found their selection process is transparent. maybe there was an issue with YSD B1, I heard the HR messed up with the results of some trainees, but we didn't face anything like that. And you know who was the Head of HR then!

It wasn't like this back in my days. The academy paid us in full and hired all 40 of us. Sad that they turned into this. Problem is that some poeple left after the academy. So it's obviously a loss for the company to pay someone 30 to 35k per month for 3 months without getting anything in return and then when they're finally supposed to work, they leave. It happened even in my batch.

post_title: Cod3m3n Solutions: A Cautionary Tale for Interns and Developers
full_review: A Harsh Reality of Cod3m3n Solutions тАУ More Like "Cod3m3n Intern Solutions" I want to highlight some of the major issues IтАЩve witnessed at Cod3m3n Solutions: 1. Exploitation of Interns: The management at Cod3m3n Solutions often hires interns and places them under immense pressure to meet tight client deadlines. In many cases, entire projects are handed over to interns with little to no senior oversight. After 3-4 months of overwork, these interns are dismissed without any real consideration or offer of permanent employment. ItтАЩs no surprise that many people now refer to the company as Cod3m3n Intern Solutions 2. Unethical Work Culture: Interns are led to believe that good performance might lead to permanent roles. However, under the leadership of G*la* M*rsh*d, this turns out to be a false hope. Interns are routinely forced to work 12-15 hours per day, often handling the responsibilities of full-time developers. Despite this, they are paid only 6000 BDT, with no overtime compensation or weekend pay. 3. Lack of Accountability Among Senior Staff: Senior developers, particularly Frontend Lead D*ep*ta S*ha, frequently avoid their responsibilities. Common excuses like "no electricity" are used to skip workdays, while in reality, they go shopping or take naps during working hours. This behavior leaves junior developers and interns to carry the workload. When deliverables are delayed, CEO Ra*i *oula blames the remaining developers instead of addressing the root of the problem. 4. Toxic Team Dynamics: Developers like D*epit* Sah* P*ja, involved in component development, often waste significant time without producing results. Their inefficiency causes delays that impact the whole team. Yet, they escape accountability while others are pressured to clean up the mess. Final Thoughts: Cod3m3n Solutions needs to seriously rethink its values and treatment of interns and junior developers. If you're considering joining this company, especially as an intern, be very cautious. DonтАЩt be fooled by empty promises. The managementтАЩs lack of ethics and the senior staffтАЩs irresponsibility create an extremely unfair and demotivating work environment.

post_title: READ BEFORE APPLY.
full_review: Don't join them if you don't hate your life much. Why? Simple, they will trick you to join them by showing off their flashy office, but yeah in that flashy office you'll struggle for the elevators. xD They'll pretend to be an MNC, but pays like a Bangladeshi Bdgobs company who you never heard of. Full of underqualified brainrot leadership, who either destroyed their careers during their study or destroyed it later here, cuz none of your skills will be useable in any other places. This company is that niche. Don't get fooled by their flashy employee branding, one of their biggest teams is marketing and a group is dedicated there only to fool you. Sometimes I don't even understand how a company operates with 9 hour working policy? Wherever that's 8 internationally! May day didn't happen for this one to happen! Oh this company frequently tends to disregard the government holidays, although apparently it follows. The company misleads you to think it to be in the IT. But it's in the financial industry. Funnier part, it has nothing registered with the central bank. This company has nothing in UAE, although it describes it to have one. The main office is in here in Bd. Another office is in SL. The only good part the company has that it pays the salary on time. Don't join here if you don't hate your life or desperately in need of money. And last piece of advise, although it pretends to be a corporate entity, it's actually a private company with a complete start up vibe. If you join in the entry level position, make sure you have the mindset to work like a clerk although you haven't signed up for it. You may work hard, but the benefits are more navigated to benefit the top management only. Not you. If you're a woman, you might face intentional harassing looks on your private parts from the seniors in some dept. Be careful.

full_review: Good culture mostly. Most people friendly. Lack of job security. No benefits - only US based company by name - no US based benefits in action. Borderline sexual harassment by upper management senior.

post_title: Where Work Feels Like Family, and Every Moment Matters.
full_review: The work environment here is both supportive and friendly. One of the standout perks is the flexibility, especially during Ramadan and Eid-ul-Adha, when we get to work remotely for over a month. This allows us to spend more quality time with our families, which is deeply appreciated. Another unique benefit is the, "Work From Tour" concept. We go on extended trips for 7-10 days, and work just a few hours a day while travelling. Its a rare blend of productivity and adventure. On top of that, every weekend ends with a sports session, fully sponsored by the company, which is treat for anyone who loves to stay active and have fun with the team. Of course, no workplace is without itтАЩs challenges. The workload can get quite intense at time, we often joke that it feels like being inside a pressure cooker! But what make the difference in our CEO. Whenever he sense the pressure is getting too high, he steps out of his room and joins us in the workspace with jokes, casual chats and lighthearted moments that instantly lift the mood. It's these small but meaningful gestures that make AppDevs feel less like a company and more like a family.

post_title: Where Mondays Don't Su*k, Ltd.
full_review: Pros: Salary is always on time тАФ usually before the month ends. Two 100% festive bonuses every year, which is rare in our industry. Great work-life balance and king of friendly environment. Fully flexible office hours тАФ come in anytime or work remotely. Opportunity to work with various tech stacks and collaborate with foreign developers, offering great exposure to new technologies. Cons: Due to insufficient profitability across global branches, the company has recently gone through workforce reductions. Management has changed employee hierarchy and business strategies multiple times. Earlier, salary increments were given twice a year, but now it's only once annually.

post_title: Best environment except salary increment and office tours
full_review: Pros: 1. One of the best in the Bangladesh 2. Prioritize Work Life Balance тЬМя╕П 3. Exceptional Leads тЩея╕П 4. On time salary ЁЯШЙ 5. Work from home. 6. Free lunch + snaks + Tea. 7. Great salary for Juniors. 8. Learning and Growth scopes. 9. Respectful to Everyone no matter in which position you are. Cons: 1. Salary structure not well defined for seniors 2. No office tours ЁЯе▓. Only teams can go by personally and it happens rare. 3. Not follow the Bangladesh Government Holiday ЁЯдж.

comments.comment_text: Not every project offers work-life balance. Although I think management is trying to do better. Promotions naturally mean addition of responsibilities, but the pay raises don't always keep up, especially at senior roles.

Hello commenter,
1. Free lunch + Snack when you do work from office. So if you do everyday work form office you will get the free lunch.
2. I don't know why your friends saying this but I have found most of the leads are there to make sure you maintain work life balance. They will never force you to do work after time.┬а
3. Every member has to go some evaluation process and after meeting a certain standard they get promotion. So each senior is well qualified for senior position.

All of my friends working on En0s!s said that they have no work-life balance.How do you get Free lunch + snacks + tea when most of the employees are remote?I've heard that staff members tend to ascend to senior positions at a rapid pace, which raises questions about potential skill gaps in the future.

post_title: Bad place to do internship
full_review: Don't come here. They don't know how to do business. The MD is just keeping it aflot because it is a PLC. The company is in loss almost every single month. Most of the managers cant even do online meetings. And they hire interns with a promise of permanent position but the truth is they will try their best to keep you as an intern as much time as possible. 0 career growth. You will learn nothing as an intern. I believe the interns are more intelligent and bring new ideas than the managers and executives over there.

post_title: Zero Leadership, Nepotism, Zero Clarity
full_review: Zero Leaders(hip) Station 23 has a clear absence of leadership amongst its upper echelon. While the CEO is amicable at first, all of it ends when it comes to any discussion or criticism that differs from his point of view. He pushes only the ideas he believes are worthwhile and belittles or simply dismisses the ideas that can help the company but didn't come from his brain or book reading. This apparent lack of trust, understanding, and openness is prevalent amongst both the CEO and CTO. Nepo-babies Nepotism is universal especially at the SBU leadership and CXO roles. CTO is a prime example. He involves himself in evertyhing that a CTO isn't in charge of, while contributing absolutely nothing to technological advancement within the company. His idea of innovation is anything that the CEO calls innovation. He honestly provides no value addition to the company or the colleagues around him. The SBU head of Innovation eyerolls is another amazing example of incompetence meets job security. A brain dead wonder child that the CEO keeps around because you have to create jobs. Doesn't matter whether they work or not. Let me not start with the HR Head, you can ask anyone who isn't from the HR team and you will question why you work hard to earn a salary. Zero Clarity The leadership team has no clue where they want to take the company as a corporation. The only BS (pun intended) they'll feed you and themselves is the NGO vision of creating jobs. How? Why? When? Where? They wouldn't be able to answer. Not because they are busy exploring the realm of unknown, but because they are restricted by the stubborn, egoistic, mindset that no one knows better than them. Conclusion Honestly, if they were the talent hub as they claim, why aren't their top talented leaders being poached away with high salaries and puffy benefits? Why do they have to keep hiring a new Marketing Head every year? The company had potential and honestly it came this far because of people like COO MJ F*rd*us, the CFO, and a handful of people who work and actually delivers.

post_title: Unprofessional Workplace with Poor Management and No Work-Life Balance
full_review: Poor Work-Life Balance: The company has an extremely poor work-life balance. There are no public holidays, not even on significant national days like December 16th, which is ridiculous. False Benefits & Mismanagement: Foods: They claim to provide fully subsidized coffee and tea, but itтАЩs a scamтАФthe coffee is terrible, and the management is disorganized. They also mention Friday lunch, but the food quality is extremely poor, likely sourced at a very cheap rate. Lack of Personal Growth: There is no opportunity for personal or professional growth since the company doesnтАЩt have any good projects. Job Insecurity: There is no notice periodтАФthey can fire employees at any time, even telling them today that they donтАЩt need to come in tomorrow. Unprofessional HR Policies: The HR policies lack professionalism and structure. Disrespectful Work Environment: Employees often use informal and impolite language (such as "Tui"), creating an unprofessional and disrespectful workplace. Poor Management & Decision-Making: The management is highly disorganized. For example, the CEO may request the implementation of Feature "A," but after completing half of it, the CTO may say that it is irrelevant to the project. This lack of proper planning leads to wasted time and effort. Advice to Management: Improve Work-Life Balance: Provide proper public holidays and ensure employees have a healthy work-life balance. Deliver Promised Benefits: If you advertise perks like free coffee, tea, and lunch, ensure they are of decent quality and not misleading. Enhance Job Security: Implement a proper notice period policy to give employees stability and confidence in their roles. Encourage Professionalism: Foster a respectful workplace by enforcing polite communication among employees and promoting a professional company culture. Revamp HR Policies: Establish structured and fair HR policies to improve employee satisfaction and retention. Ensure┬аBetter Project Planning: Improve decision-making by aligning leadership teams. Avoid unnecessary changes that waste employeesтАЩ time and effort. Invest in Employee Growth: Provide opportunities for learning, skill development, and meaningful projects to support career progression.

post_title: Unprofessional and Mismanaged
full_review: Pros: Great place to learn automation as an intern тАФ ideal for gaining experience within the first 6 months. Opportunity to work on real projects and gain hands-on experience . Cons: Frequent buffer time cuts due to unscheduled prayer breaks. High-pressure, stressful environment with unrealistic expectations. Salary issues : payments are frequently delayed, and often only half the agreed amount is paid . Lack of structure : Only one person (Asif Rouf) handles HR, QA, digital marketing, and management roles, leading to disorganization. Uses false references to a non-existent тАЬUSAтАЭ or тАЬMalaysiaтАЭ management to create fear and control. Empty promises of salary increases or full-time roles, which are never fulfilled. Interns and staff are kept in temporary roles for over 2 years without progression. Constant pressure to stay active in workflows just to increase log counts , even when there is no meaningful work. No professional team structure , career development path, or clear communication channels. Advice to Management: Please stop trying to manage everything alone. Build a real team with defined roles and responsibilities. Be transparent with salaries , and stop making promises you donтАЩt intend to keep. Respect your employeesтАЩ time and effort , and stop fostering a fear-based work culture . Establish a proper HR and management system to ensure growth, fairness, and professional development.

post_title: Worst Interview Ever
full_review: I would like to start with a well-presented story about my interview experience at W3. Between February and March, I applied for the position of Software Engineer (Backend). One day, a gentleman called me for a pre-screening interview. Although I had applied for the Backend position, he asked me if I knew JavaScript, React, HTML, and CSS. It was at that moment I realized that perhaps his background wasn't technical, or he didnтАЩt have a clear understanding of software development. Later, I was invited to take an assessment. While it was supposed to be done online, I was asked to complete it in the office within two hours. The assessment had nothing to do with the job description they had provided. Next, I was selected for the interview. There were three people on the technical panel. One of them, who had a rather harsh attitude, was asking questions in a way that felt more like a university viva, with no courtesy whatsoever. Another person who was conducting the interview had a very unclear way of speakingтАФhe would just say "Answer the question" without explaining much. The third person kept asking the same question 4-5 times, and at one point, even asked about topics unrelated to the job description. After the interview, the HR told me they would let me know about their decision, but didnтАЩt clarify if it would be positive or negative. When I later called the HR, the same person told me, тАЬYou will be informed,тАЭ and asked me to wait. After 11 days of waiting, feeling frustrated, I withdrew my application. Sixteen days later, I received a call saying I wasnтАЩt selected because the vacancy had been filled. They mentioned they would post job openings again in about a week. I couldnтАЩt help but wonder how many openings they had each month. Had the HR been upfront from the beginning and informed me that only positive outcomes would be communicated, I wouldnтАЩt have waited this long. This experience was highly disappointing and sends a negative message about their interview process and company culture.

post_title: Unprofessional Management and Unethical Practices
full_review: I joined the Company as a Junior Frontend Developer, where the focus was primarily on CMS-based development, including news portals, small business websites, and e-commerce platforms. While the technical work was straightforward and offered some early career exposure, my overall experience was disappointing due to serious issues with management and company ethics. The most concerning aspect was the unprofessional behavior of the CEO, who failed to pay my salary for two months. I was not the only one affectedтАФanother colleague also faced similar issues. Despite multiple follow-ups, the situation was never resolved, and accountability was lacking at all levels. Additionally, the internal processes, including payroll and time tracking (calculation of dues, etc.), were poorly managed, creating a chaotic work environment. These issues overshadowed any potential learning opportunities. Advice to Management : Treat employees with fairness and integrity. Transparent and ethical business practices are fundamental to building a sustainable and respected company.

post_title: Interview Experience
full_review: Interview Experience Review тАУ Rob! Axiata (Infrastructure Role) I recently interviewed for a technical infrastructure position at Robi Axiata, and IтАЩd like to share my experience for the benefit of other professionals in similar fields. The role was advertised as a technical position requiring substantial experience and multiple vendor certifications тАФ which set the expectation for a process focused on system architecture, infrastructure management, or vendor-specific technologies (e.g., Cisco, VMware, Red Hat, etc.). However, the actual interview process diverged significantly from this expectation. Format: Mode : Entirely online. The test was heavily focused on analytical reasoning and business-related scenarios. The content resembled something more aligned with a Bachelor of Business Administration (BBA) curriculum тАФ covering topics like market strategy, cost analysis, and general business logic. Unfortunately, not a single question was technical or related to infrastructure, systems engineering, or enterprise IT operations. This was quite surprising, considering the role was pitched as one requiring technical experience and industry certifications. So I did not proceed past the assessment stage, likely because my background is more technical than business-focused. It was disappointing, as I was prepared to demonstrate my technical proficiency, but there was no opportunity to do so. Advice to Future Candidates : Unless the job description is revised, be prepared for a business-heavy initial screening тАФ even for technical roles. I dont know how that makes sense

post_title: Think Twice Before Joining This Company
full_review: This organization once had the potential to be one of the leading software companies in Bangladesh. In its early days, when it was smaller, the work environment was relatively healthy. However, with a headcount now exceeding 450, the situation has deteriorated significantly. Key Issues to Consider: Lack of Professional Growth: There are no structured annual reviews or clear career development plans for most employees. Promotions are rare, and feedback is often vague or non-existent. Toxic Leadership: The current Bangladesh country lead has repeatedly failed to deliver on promises. He lacks vision and technical expertise, often relying on buzzwords rather than real substance. Unqualified Senior Staff: Certain high-paid employees have been in the company for years without making any meaningful contributions. Their presence speaks more to internal politics than performance. Corrupt and Inefficient Management: Junior employees often suffer from micromanagement, lack of proper onboarding, and inconsistent workloads. Some teams experience unreasonable pressure, affecting work-life balance. QA and Product Quality Issues: Despite having a large QA team, product quality has noticeably declined. Basic functionalities are not properly tested, making system stability a recurring issue. Non-Technical Teams Mismanagement: Team leads in departments like Global, Marketing, Design, and Support lack professionalism. Misuse of office funds for personal or low-impact activities is a serious concern. Accountability and Financial Transparency: Unjustified salary deductions under the guise of taxes, without proper breakdowns, are common. Complaints go unheard or are dismissed without proper investigation. Poor Facilities and Benefits: The quality and availability of office-provided food are consistently subpar. Despite the company promoting a vibrant office culture, reality falls far short. Resource Misallocation: While cost-cutting is affecting employee benefits and raises, the company continues to invest in new buildings and unrelated business ventures. This raises serious questions about priorities. The work culture is marred by favoritism, lack of transparency, and minimal regard for employee welfare. If you're considering joining, do your due diligence and speak to former or current employees before making a decision.

post_title: My Experience at a Job Test for an Assistant Software Engineer Position
full_review: I recently took a written exam for Mi11enn!um Information Solution Ltd.'s Assistant Software Engineer employment. Since programming is the focus of the work, I naturally assumed that the test would have questions about it. I was shocked to see that there was not a single programming question on the test. Rather, it was jam-packed with multiple-choice questions that only addressed English grammar and mathematics. It was odd and frustrating that there was no evaluation of actual programming skills, even though I recognize the importance of logical reasoning and communication abilities. Should the position entail coding and software development, the assessment procedure must to take that into account. Candidates are not given the opportunity to showcase their technical skills or establish their suitability for the role in a test that contains no programming substance. I was a little disheartened by this encounter. In my opinion, employers ought to better match the duties of the position with the hiring evaluations.

post_title: Where Work Feels Like Family, and Every Moment Matters.
full_review: The work environment here is both supportive and friendly. One of the standout perks is the flexibility, especially during Ramadan and Eid-ul-Adha, when we get to work remotely for over a month. This allows us to spend more quality time with our families, which is deeply appreciated. Another unique benefit is the тАЬWork From TourтАЭ concept. We go on extended trips, sometimes for 7 to 10 days, and work just a few hours a day while traveling. ItтАЩs a rare blend of productivity and adventure. On top of that, every weekend ends with a sports session, fully sponsored by the company, which is a treat for anyone who loves to stay active and have fun with the team. Of course, no workplace is without its challenges. The workload can get quite intense at times, we often joke that it feels like being inside a pressure cooker! But what makes the difference is our CEO. Whenever he senses the pressure is getting too high, he steps out of his room and joins us in the workspace with jokes, casual chats, and lighthearted moments that instantly lift the mood. ItтАЩs these small but meaningful gestures that make AppDevs feel less like a company and more like a family.

post_title: A Supportive and Friendly Workplace That Prioritizes People
full_review: Working at Hubxpert for the past year as a mid-level UI/UX designer has been a truly positive experience. The overall vibe here is warm and welcomingтАФcolleagues are approachable, and collaboration feels effortless. The company fosters a balanced work culture that values both productivity and personal well-being, which creates a healthy and motivating atmosphere. One of the most memorable experiences was our winter retreat. I attended with my spouse, and she had an amazing time. She even remarked that it felt more like a fun university trip with friends and family than a typical office event. This reflects the genuine sense of community we have here. Leadership is both supportive and empathetic. I suffer from a back issue and needed a month of rest. Without hesitation, the CEO suggested I work from home to recover. Later, during a difficult period, I was planning an international trip to recharge. I was nervous to ask for leave, but the CEO not only approved itтАФhe encouraged me to extend it to enjoy the experience fully. He often reminds us that happy employees are essential to a successful company, and he truly lives by that principle. The work environment is comfortable and visually appealing. We also enjoy perks like unlimited coffee, which may seem small but is a real productivity booster. When I faced issues with high blood pressure, our HR lead brought in a monitoring machine just for me, and colleagues still regularly check in to see how IтАЩm doing. That level of care is rare and means a lot. Outside work, we engage in activities like football after office hours, which helps us unwind and build stronger team bonds. I also learned to play table tennis hereтАФsomething I really enjoyed, and although we had to leave it behind in the new office, I still miss it. Professionally, working with HubXpertтАЩs diverse clients has sharpened my design skills and made me more efficient. It has also helped me build strong relationships with both the product and development teams.

post_title: The perfect place to kill your dreams
full_review: If your ambition in life is to slowly turn your brain as smooth as a baby's bottom, then this place is for you. That's right- you've got the toxic work culture with several sprinkles of office politics, the daily comedy show called management with inhuman leadership lacking an ounce of empathy for their subs all in one place. It's the perfect environment to kill your hopes and dreams of having a better life. Some teams have leaders who lack accountability despite several people leaving after being publicly humiliated by said leaders. HR is just there as a label offering no proper solutions to repeated incidents. Seniors will bully you and then make a Hindi serial plot-worthy storyline to save their asses while shifting the blame to juniors every chance they get. They'll force you to do work on government holidays (even Eid) with no compensation or benefits. And then boast about the amazing radioactive chicken served in the cafeteria that seems to get everyone sick every few days. Absolute joke of a system that has nothing new to offer. The UI itself is ┬аso shitty it looks like some colorblind dude designed it in 2016 (ржкрж╛ржпрж╝ржЦрж╛ржирж╛). Constantly releasing useless features that make things harder than they need to be. And pressuring juniors to get work done ┬аby unrealistic deadlines - all for the sake of stroking their egos that their team is better. Will have you working as late as 12 am and end up crediting others for your work. Oh and asking for leaves is taboo - it's almost like asking for one of their kidneys. They will have you explain and over-share all the juicy details of your illness to prove why you need a day off - what on earth could possibly be more important than the office? The health insurance is probably there to cover the costs when you eventually get a heart attack from all the stress of getting yelled at or discredited daily. When you join this place you are essentially signing up to a brain dead cult who will worship toxic leadership for some free food (ржЕржЦрж╛ржжрзНржп) and a free ride.
