post_title: The beauty and the burnout
full_review: With a strong tech stack, good coding practices, and a welcoming environment for making an impact at scale, the company could have been one of the best small to mid-tier tech firms in Dhaka. But some outliers and caveats turn it into a claustrophobic hell for your mind. Tech Stack and Practices: Love it. It needs a bit of modernization. While traditional best practices are vital for foundational strength, adopting newer technologies wouldn't hurt. In fact, it might boost efficiency for both the product and the employees. HR & Admin: Supportive and professional. Their efforts are better than some other places IтАЩve seen, though a bit more speed and organizational clarity would help. Management: At times, it feels like the office is run by a one-man army, not entirely in a bad way. YouтАЩll find ten solid reasons to align with the chiefтАЩs vision, but if thereтАЩs even one valid reason to disagree, it deserves to be heard and resolved. The commander-in-chief must show compassion and acknowledge that lives are asynchronous. without breathing space, it wonтАЩt be a sustainable place in the long run. Timing: Comparatively flexible, but there's a silent expectation that employees should stay until evening or beyond. The worst culture at IdeaScale is the invisible peer pressure to stay late or push serious work toward or past the end of the day to allign with some employee's schedule. A red flag. Perks: Okayish. No complaints. Now, letтАЩs talk about red flags no one acknowledges: Support staff: which shouldтАЩve been the least of anyoneтАЩs concerns, become more prominent than they should. Either train them properly or find better alternatives. Synchronization with foreign entities : As an employee, itтАЩs a nightmare to predict whatтАЩs going on company-wide, how much you should care depending on your role, or what you need to do to stay afloat. And again, no one enjoys being stuck around the office with colleagues after 8 hours of work.

post_title: Unrealistic Expectations for Junior Designers: A Reflection
full_review: On the 30th of last month, I had an interview with a company named AlgoSoft. Before that, they gave me a task to complete. The day after I submitted the task, they suddenly called me at 12 PM and said the interview would be at 1 PM. I was just shockedтАФwhat kind of madness is this? Anyway, I attended the interview. They asked me if I was familiar with iOS design guidelines. I responded that I donтАЩt know them fully but I do know some basics. Then they went on with some typical template-like questions such as: what is your design process, how do you solve problems, how do you handle file handover, and how do you manage when the same task gets repeated feedback again and again? Can you do this? Can you do that? Now regarding the work scheduleтАФ Their working hours are from 10 AM to 6 PM. Since I have my semester finals in May, I told them I would need around 3 hours off on exam days, but I would cover that time at night. Still, they asked how many hours I could work, especially on weekends. Basically, IтАЩd need to work the entire week. In fact, working 24/7 would be even better for them! And the most ridiculous part isтАФthey expect all of this for just 10,000 BDT per month. They gave me a task, took my interview, yet didn't even bother to inform me whether I was selected or not. I just don't understand what exactly they expect for 10,000 taka. They donтАЩt mention any of these excessive demands in the job post. They just give out tasks unnecessarily and waste peopleтАЩs time with interviews. My question is: how much can you really expect from an entry-level junior designer? The design should be top-notch, problem-solving skills should be top-notch, and they want someone whoтАЩs mentally prepared to work 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.

post_title: Excellent overall!
full_review: Pros: Excellent work-life balance. Good and responsive management. Flat structure with no friction during communication. Anyone can communicate freely with anyone. Most importantly, we have some amazing colleagues! Some really big clients, mostly from Norway. Excellent work culture. Unlimited breakfast, lunch, and snacks throughout the day. Transportation facility. Health insurance. Cons: Provident fund and profit sharing are missing. These would be good to have for a company of this caliber. post_title: The Death of Beautiful Opportunities
full_review: I would recommend them, being so potential in this field, they have lots of opportunities to improve all of their fallen sides for a better growth of the company. The most important thing I believe is that a company will improve faster if the developers are learning and growing up with the company. So ensure their learning scopes and do not go for pressurised work. Divide the team in multiple sectors. Don't expect one to serve everything together. A business must need to be well structured and well managed to have sustainability. Get out of your comfort zone and get ready for the future. Please do focus on that first. Just ensuring people say 'Yes' or 'No' based on your expectations is not a good practice. Let them explore more and go beyond all limits. Maybe they can help you to get better outcomes. Look for their motivations so that they never wonder about leaving the job ASAP. Help them to feel like they are working on their own stuffs. Never underestimate your co-workers even if they are freshers. Maybe their learning and thinking out-of-the-box ability is wider than you think. And last thing, but not the least, do not bargain with salary increments based on their skills, and never try to compare someone with others, as people have different types of ability on their own scope of work.

post_title: DonтАЩt Evolve, Operate Poorly: The Real Cost of Clueless DevOps
full_review: I've been working at this company for over 1.5 - 2 years now. Today, I want to specifically talk about the DevOps situation. Frankly, it's one of the most frustrating and limiting parts of the entire engineering process here. The current DevOps setup is fundamentally brokenтАФanchored in outdated practices, rigid mindsets, and a refusal to evolve. We're in 2025, but you'd never guess it by looking at the tooling or workflows. Everything is VM-based, poorly automated, and manually managed. CI/CD pipelines are either non-existent or duct-taped together. Docker usage is basic at best, and modern cloud-native practices are nowhere to be seen. Whenever someone tries to introduce something betterтАФsomething scalable, secure, and aligned with actual industry standardsтАФthey're met with the same recycled excuses: тАЬSecurity risk.тАЭ тАЬWe understand, but itтАЩs not possible here.тАЭ тАЬWeтАЩll do it the way weтАЩve been doing.тАЭ Or the classic: тАЬWeтАЩve done it in other places like this.тАЭ This resistance to progress doesnтАЩt just slow things downтАФit actively harms developer productivity and blocks genuine innovation. Teams lose countless hours due to infrastructure limitations and avoidable bottlenecks. ItтАЩs not just about lack of knowledgeтАФitтАЩs about ego and insecurity dressed as authority. The most painful part is watching junior DevOps team members, with barely any real-world experience, argue like theyтАЩve built AWS from scratch. Their confidence is inversely proportional to their depth. There's no depth, no accountability, and no roadmap for improvement. At some point, this has to changeтАФnot just for the sake of engineering velocity, but for the basic dignity of working in a modern tech environment. Enough with the excuses. These DevOps should either grow with the industry or make room for people who will.

post_title: A Company with Potential, Undermined by Leadership Gaps and Internal Politics
full_review: Having been at Pathao for a substantial period, IтАЩve witnessed both its growth and its decline. While the company continues to offer timely salaries, flexible work hours, and an excellent office environment, these benefits are overshadowed by deeper organizational issues that are increasingly difficult to ignore. 1. Human Resources (HR): HR functions more as a symbolic entity rather than an empowered department. When employees raise concerns, they are often redirected back to line managers. There is a noticeable lack of accountability, and their inflated sense of authority doesnтАЩt align with their actual influence. 2. Operations тАУ A Case of Mismanagement: Food Operations: The department is overloaded with managers while execution-level roles are scarce. Favoritism is rampant, with hires being made from prior connections rather than merit. Key leaders have resigned due to internal conflicts, and now supply operations have been irrationally shifted under the product team without any documented handover. The order volume is consistently dropping, and the team struggles to compete even with emerging, smaller competitors. Rides Operations: The strategy remains stagnant and reliant on burn rather than innovation. Following the departure of experienced managers, current leadership lacks the maturity and professionalism needed to steer the team forward. Toxic behavior, including disrespect toward senior staff and unresolved complaints about team leads, has driven away valuable employees. Pay Team: There is a lack of direction, with unclear objectives. Public criticism from the CEO toward the department head during a company forum further reflected poor internal alignment. Courier: The exodus of experienced employees has left the team visibly struggling, despite public portrayals of stability. 3. Product Team: This team now dominates most decisions, often at the cost of collaboration and respect for other departments. ThereтАЩs a growing over-reliance on interns to execute core functions, which raises concerns about long-term sustainability and knowledge retention. 4. Accounts Department: Processes remain outdated and highly manual, with inefficiencies being the norm. Despite these shortcomings, the department operates with little accountability, likely due to the influence of its leadership. 5. CEOтАЩs Core Team and Political Interests: The CEOтАЩs inner circle appears to prioritize loyalty over competence. Some individuals openly leverage their personal relationship with the CEO, even working remotely for extended periods with minimal contribution. More concerning is the CEOтАЩs increasing focus on political involvement over business growth. Initial attempts to align with the NCP were unsuccessful, and now efforts are being made to build ties with BNP. This shifting political interest not only distracts from business priorities but also reflects a concerning lack of strategic clarity at the top. 6. Customer Experience (CX): The department has developed a toxic culture that affects both internal morale and external service standards. Final Thoughts: At present, many employees are staying simply because of the security, flexible schedules, and on-time pay. Passion for the companyтАЩs mission and long-term vision is fading. Until Pathao addresses its leadership vacuum, political distractions, internal favoritism, and lack of merit-based progression, the company will continue to decline in both performance and employee trust.

post_title: Say What You Want, But DonтАЩt Let Your Upbringing Take a Vacation
reviewer_role: A Frustrated but still decent human being.
full_review: IтАЩm just another employee trying to survive the 9 to 6 life. Saw Deshi Mula pop up a few times and thoughtтАФokay, interesting! People are finally talking about their work experiences in the tech scene. Not bad. Some posts are actually useful. You get an idea of what to expect from certain companies. But let me be real, some of the reviews? Bro, relax. YouтАЩd think people were held hostage in the office basement with no food and WiFi. Calling out HR like they personally ruined your childhood, cursing managers like they stole your lunch money. I get it. Not every job is sunshine and bonus cheques. Some companies do have serious issues. And those should be talked about. But sometimes it feels like people are just angry at life and found a place to vent anonymously. And letтАЩs not forget, you worked or may be working there . You earned or maybe earning from there. You survived or maybe surving (maybe even learnedor learning). So this whole тАЬI hate everything about this placeтАЭ vibe? Jei plate e khabo setai futa korbo. If it was that bad, why not leave? Find a better place. Or better yetтАФstart your own thing. Make your own rules, build your dream company, hire your dream HR team. Then letтАЩs see how easy it is to make everyone happy ЁЯШМ Deshi Mula could actually be a force for good. But it needs a bit more honesty and a bit less hate. Criticism is great, just donтАЩt lose the plot.

post_title: Fake USA Mula.
full_review: App5cod3 is a software company who offers Kubernetes native database solutions. App5cod3 hires highly rated competitive programmers, mostly rated 1700+. After covid, one of my university junior shared a job post of App5cod3 with me and i applied. And within hours the CEO replied with a personality test and fixed the technical rounds. The rounds went very smooth and CEO offered me verbally and asked me when i can join. I asked him for time as i was interviewing in FAANGs and CEO agreed. I felt CEO bro is very cool as he himself was an ex google and ex amazon, and i eventually joined App5cod3 after 5 months. The joining day, their only HR came with a Half litre water bottle and a khata and said "Welcome to App5cod3". The first three months you got the learning period, when you had to learn Go, Kubernetes, etc. You got to learn hell out of it. Things were good till these days, you'll eventually know the unprofessionalism of the company. From the first day, CEO starts micro-managing every individual, and expect people to have no life with deshi salary like him. I saw most of the employees are frustrated as the CEO was very rude on every occasion. And as most of the employees joined as a fresher, they didn't really know how to deal with this. So eventually employees are working 9-9 with their deshi salaries and handling client like Nokia, Vimeo. CEO creates unrealistic pressures on the employees and behave as they are nothing towards him. He even call some employees at 3 am at night to fix a client issue and asked not to late next day. After a year at App5cod3, i felt i was doing redundant work and was about to ask CEO to switch projects but then i saw the real CEO. The lifeless guy fired an employee who asked him to switch a project. So i never asked and felt very insecure. From my first day, as i share him my vision and the interviews in FAANGS, he started to think i would leave the company anytime. So he started digging things with seniors on what i do day by day, and tried to put me in a position to not to do such things. And eventually things went worse when i started handing clients and he expects the same or more than the previous one in the projects. I mean the 3 AM call with my "Highly rated Competitive Profile" and he thinks i would do ironman things with my deshi salary. At this point, you might think things are only high pressure work with deshi salaries. Things are worse on other things. The "Headquartered at USA" never exists and what he mean that lives in USA and work remotely from there. His father do the "kerani/manager" job for him, and the office actually are some flats in his father's buildings. The manager's main job is to come every half an hour or hour period to fixed the AC temperatures to 26 degree and switch off the fans. And alert the employees not to change the temperature and not to turn on the fan. These are the simple example of what CEO family does and i may not put everything here. The only office stuff is the "daroan of the building" who seems much professional than the HR himself. The HR who was previously is a bkash officer, doesn't even know how to give starting speech on occasions. His main job is to spy on employees on what they do or speaks. Anyway that's not the point also. Now come to the leave policies, they say you'll have 2 weeks leave. What they meant 10 days with the weekend and 1 week sick leave meants 5 days. And if you take extra leave, then things might get extra worse. So eventually after two years, after speaking out on things and some incidents i got fired. ЁЯдгЁЯдг. And the reason was "highly rated competitive programmer did nothing in two years" and yet the people like CEO paid the salaries. Anyway in just 7 days i eventually got a job offer with almost double the salary of CEO's App5cod3. Anyway my suggestions are to research from the previous employees before joining App5cod3. Or better do it on your own risk. As it was long ago, i might have forgot so many things but i strongly that this is the worst company for "highly rated competitive programmer". So what did i gain? I gain some "highly rated colleagues"┬а who are shining in every corner of the world.

post_title: An excellent environment for developers looking to apply their theoretical knowledge to practical, real-world projects
full_review: Port0n1cs has established a strong reputation in the software industry within our country. In all my previous roles, I never encountered the level of technical challenges that IтАЩve faced here. The company primarily focuses on developing large-scale software solutionsтАФoften catering to user bases of 50 to 70 millionтАФparticularly within the telecommunications sector. Even working on a single MVP (Minimum Viable Product) can completely change your perspective on software development. The salary structure is significantly higher compared to other companies in the industry. Salary increments and career advancement are purely based on performance. Favoritism or internal politics have no place here. The management team is highly engaged and supportive of employee well-being and productivity. The company offers a very flexible and developer-friendly work culture. Most teams consist of highly skilled and collaborative developers, making it an excellent environment for growth and learning. The MVP phase can be extremely demanding, often leading to intense pressure and tight deadlines. Management should consider better support and planning during this stage. Apart from the salary, there are minimal additional employee benefits. The Eid bonus is modest and could be increased to better reflect employee contributions.

post_title: Ultra Toxic Work Culture Rooted in Ultra Incompetent CEO
full_review: The most damaging aspect of this company is its CEO, who embodies unprofessionalism to the core. Not only does he assume every role imaginable.Senior Developer (Frontend & Backend), Team Lead, HR, Salesperson, UI/UX Designer, and CEO. This chaotic centralization benefits only his ego while leaving employees directionless, overburdened, and entirely unsupported. There is no structure, no mentorship, and absolutely no leadership. His inability to build a functioning team or cultivate a productive work environment results in a disorganized mess where employees are often isolated and left to fend for themselves with no collaboration or guidance. This company doesnтАЩt just ignore employee well-being, it actively destroys it. Feedback is not welcomed; in fact, itтАЩs treated as crime. You are a puppet, not a person, and your opinions carry zero weight. The basic facilities are beyond unacceptable. Food is not only delayed, often arriving at 3 or 4 PM, but frequently spoiled or rotten. Insects in coffee, dirty bottles, and unsanitary conditions are the norm. Recreation is non-existent, yearly leaves are minimal, and there is a clear, deliberate attempt to extract as much work from employees without offering a shred of appreciation or support. This is not a workplace,itтАЩs a machine that grinds people down and throws them away when theyтАЩre no longer useful.

post_title: Toxic Culture with No Room for Growth
full_review: Promotions are not performance-based but rather depend on how upper management perceives you. The workplace is riddled with office politics, creating a toxic environment. Salary increments fall below industry standards, and there is little to no room for career growth, regardless of hard work or dedication. The absence of experienced senior professionals further hampers development and mentorship. Additionally, several office rules are unprofessional and unethical, showing little regard for employee well-being or satisfaction. Advice to Leadership: Implement a transparent, merit-based promotion system. Take active steps to eliminate toxic office politics. Ensure salary increments align with industry standards. Recognize and reward hard work and dedication. Hire experienced senior professionals to guide and mentor teams. Reevaluate and reform unprofessional office rules to prioritize employee satisfaction and ethical practices.

post_title: Good company with some cons!
full_review: Xpeed is a nice company for both entry level people and also seniors. If you're just starting, you can learn many good things easily. The old office was kinda small for 50+ people but now the new HQ is very big and has modern facilities. The work culture overall is good. There is no bossy attitude. But some people use the facilities wrongly and then the management become strict for everyone. It will be better if they give notice to rule breakers or punish them only. Punishing everyone because of few is not fair. Besides this, salary system is good, salary comes in time, also profit sharing, bonuses, retreats, free lunch and average level breakfast is there. All things fine. CTO might be annoying for some but actually he is good guy. If you explain things properly, he will not misbehave. But you have to be confident while talking with him. CEO is also nice and a good man. He helps but get annoyed easily by other peopleтАЩs comment (those people are mainly reason for bad image of managment). HR is okay person too. The way he talks may look rude but if you know him, heтАЩs okay. In general, Xpeedstudio is a good company.

post_title: It's not even a company
full_review: The existence of App3code is a perfect example of how broken and poor the condition of our software industry is,so much so that some of the brightest young minds in our country are forced to even consider joining this trash, family run business. This company/CEO himself directly and indirectly violates some of the core principles and dignity of our profession, cultivating a toxic environment by exploiting the insecurities and fears of young freshers. Perhaps the only solution lies in raising awareness and uplifting our entire software industry, ensuring fair and sufficient opportunities for talented freshers, so that companies like App3code are left with no choice but to correct themselves and improve.

post_title: Freedom for Employees
full_review: Vivasoft is one of the most flexible companies in bangladesh. They provide freedom to the employee. It's a big thing. You can go through the maximum posts from the deshimula. You will notice that maximum companies does not give freedom to their employees. Vivasoft is exception. They provide a nice work life balance. Someone may criticise their culture and about their freedom. But I found it is not harmful for other employees. The praciticing muslims have their oppotunity to say their prayers. I noticed that everyday in every Waqts Salat there is a Jamaat in front of the office premises and no one have problem with it. In summary, everyone remains with their own religion. They respect others religion. I have notice maximum of the posts are disgraceful. They are highlighted so much. Maximum of the posts are the result of their own failure. Though there are some cons. Even the tech giant also have some cons. But the way they are bulliying is so unacceptable. We expect more constructive discussions or reviews. Thank you for reading.

post_title: From Fintech to Familytech: The Real Up4y Story
full_review: Upay once had a lot of potential, but thatтАЩs all in the past now. Poor leadership, false promises, and a complete lack of accountability have made it a place where real talent has no future. ThereтАЩs no proper performance evaluation here. Hardworking people are often ignored, while others move up based on visibility or favoritism. Your actual skills donтАЩt matter much, your contributions are barely noticed. At one point, the entire tech team was moved to UC8 BankтАФnot for any strategic reason, but mainly to serve the personal interests of a few senior people. This so-called "transfer" came with reduced salaries, fewer benefits. One of the most absurd rules: if youтАЩre late three times, they can deduct one full dayтАЩs salary(Bank Rules). Despite long hours and dedication, salary increments are either tiny or nonexistent. And whenever someone gets an offer from another company, management often tries to keep them with fake promisesтАФthings that never materialize. Worse still, if someone decides to leave, there have been cases where management actively calls the new employer and spreads false information about the employee. Imagine someone trying to move forward in their career, only to have their old employer try to sabotage it behind the scenes. ItтАЩs toxic. And then thereтАЩs the nepotism. This is one of the ugliest parts of the culture. Some employees are clearly there because theyтАЩre someoneтАЩs cousin or brotherтАФlike the C*OтАЩs nephew or a team leadтАЩs sibling. These people often do nothing but still get all the benefits: big raises, and special treatment. To avoid criticism, some even deny their family ties at work. That said, not everything is negative. The people you work withтАФyour fellow employeesтАФare incredibly friendly and supportive. The internal environment, in terms of day-to-day collaboration and bonding, is actually very good. It's just unfortunate that the bigger problems come from the top.

post_title: Reconsidered, Reassessed, Re-rejected тАУ Thanks for the Hope, I Guess?
reviewer_role: Interview Candidate for Senior DevOps Engineer
full_review: So I had heard a lot of good things about 3n05i5 and applied to one of their openings recently. Went through the usual: online problem-solving round тЖТ technical interview. The tech interviewers were actually nice and helpful, even though I struggled with quite a few questions. Honestly, I wasnтАЩt too proud of my performance тАФ felt like a 50-50 shot, in my opinion. I felt the outcome could go either way тАФ didnтАЩt get my hopes up, but didnтАЩt write it off either. They said IтАЩd hear back in 2 weeks, but I had to follow up after 35 days to finally get a rejection email around the 40-day mark. Fair enough, figured I needed to improve and I moved on. But hereтАЩs where it gets weird: about a week later, I got a call from their HR saying they reassessed and wanted to move forward with an HR interview. I agreed and joined the soonest available slot. The session went well тАФ no tech, just discussions on culture, salary expectations, benefits, etc. Genuinely felt positive. They said theyтАЩd get back in 7тАУ10 days. I followed up on day 10 тАФ they replied saying they needed more time and they're тАЬstill evaluatingтАЭ. On day 16, I received the┬аexact same template rejection saying I wasnтАЩt a strong match тАЬbased on current competencies.тАЭ Now hereтАЩs the confusing part: If my competencies werenтАЩt a fit, why even recall me for an HR Round after rejecting once? And why keep me hanging for another 20 days just to send another same vague rejection? Sent a polite email asking for a brief feedback тАФ got ghosted. Not trying to rant, just sharing my experience so others can go in with realistic expectations.

post_title: A Corporate Disaster in Slow Motion
full_review: Once seen as a decent workplace, it has now become a textbook example of how poor leadership can destroy a company from within. What was once an employee-friendly environment is now a suffocating swamp of ego, favoritism, and incompetence тАФ a place where sycophancy is valued more than skill, and decisions are driven by vanity rather than vision. At the heart of this collapse are the MD, his sons, and an utterly clueless CFO тАФ a trio whose decisions are sinking the company like a stone. Many of the companyтАЩs true leaders, the ones who genuinely cared about people and performance, have either been pushed out or left in disgust. What remains is a circus of yes-men and pillow-passing managers who play politics while the company burns. The CFO deserves special mention, not for brilliance, but for breathtaking failure. While laying off 50+ employees to "cut costs," he still manages to pocket a salary equivalent to all of them combined. Business strategy? Nonexistent. Financial foresight? Laughable. His presence alone is a liability, and as long as he clings to power, the company will continue its downward spiral. Even basic operational decency has eroded. it was once known for paying salaries on the first day of the month тАФ now, even that is being delayed under this mismanagement. As for promotions and increments, the corruption is in plain sight: the C-Level and his inner circle quietly gift themselves 30% raises and new titles, while hardworking teams get crumbs тАФ 0%, maybe 5% if theyтАЩre lucky. The message is clear: at this company, loyalty to leadership outweighs loyalty to the company. Skill, effort, and performance mean nothing unless they come with a bottle of oil and a willingness to massage egos. So if you're planning to work at this company, donтАЩt forget to pack a bottle of Pure Oil тАФ not for your back, but for the MD and his court of clowns.

post_title: A Mixed Bag of Talent and Mismanagement
full_review: I had the opportunity to work at this company for a significant period and experienced both its highs and lows. HereтАЩs an honest take based on my time there: Pros: Incredible Development Team: The programmers, especially senior developers and team leads, are extremely talented, supportive, and passionate. The peer- to- peer learning environment is excellent, making it a great place to grow technically. Friendly Culture Within the Dev Team: The camaraderie among the developers creates a positive atmosphere. Despite external challenges, the dev team sticks together. Learning Opportunities: If you're self- motivated, you'll find plenty of chances to explore new technologies and sharpen your skills. Cons: Nepotism & Politics at the Top: Unfortunately, the upper management is plagued with favoritism and internal politics. This significantly affects transparency and decision- making. Job Insecurity: ThereтАЩs always an underlying fear of sudden termination, often without clear justification or notice. Oil Over Skill: Career growth often depends more on тАЬ oilingтАЭ ( flattery and favoritism) than merit or performance. ItтАЩs disheartening to see talent being overlooked. Poor Project Management: Projects often lack proper planning, timelines, and scope management, leading to frequent deadline pressure and burnout for the dev team. Non- technical Managers: Most managers lack a technical background, making it hard for them to understand developersтАЩ challenges or give proper guidance. Weak Business & System Analysis: Due to the absence of proper analysis, developers bear the brunt of chaotic project execution. HR Disconnect: The HR team isnтАЩt tech- oriented, resulting in poor handling of developer- specific issues and lack of basic empathy. Delayed Salaries: Salary disbursement is often late, with payments sometimes being made as late as the 20th of the month. Lack of Basic Facilities: Even small essentials like pens, notebooks, and tissues arenтАЩt providedтАФ basic items that every office should ensure. No Structured Evaluation: Performance reviews are either irregular or entirely absent, making growth paths unclear and demotivating for many. Final Thoughts: This company has immense potential, primarily because of its amazing developer base. However, unless the management rethinks its approach and addresses the structural and cultural flaws, good talent will continue to be demotivated or move on. Great for early- career learning, but not ideal for long- term career growth unless major changes are made.

post_title: Improved a lot, good company for career growth and stability
full_review: It's a company that grew from very small as I heard, i have been working here for 3 years now. Good things: multiple increments based on performance. No boss, we mention each other by bhai brothers even the ceo. No kpi pressures. Always on time salary payments. Sometimes, we got eid bonus 1month earlier. 1 hour flexible time schedule. Very nice looking and refreshing office ( the new one). Collaboration among the teams is very high, feels like "someone is always saving my back". During every task development, upon team's recommendation (upon difficulty) requirements may change where necessary. Having a dedicated QA feels safe. Women has separated section, mostly home office. Yearly profit share bonus is a huge deal. Dedicated Prayer place. With lunch and breakfast. Yearly awards ensure everyone gets some, eventually:D Cto, ceo, hr is just doing there job to run the company smoothly since 2015, if someone doesn't like it, that's his/ her personal issue. As far as I know, within these 3 years no developer left the company due to any clashes. Some other disappointments: Previously we used to have dedicated eid gifts which is missing this year. That felt really heart touching. This year, missing the company feedback form which is a great way to give minor feedbacks like "water filter system can be improved". Previously we had very little Yearly leave, but good thing, this year we r getting a total count as per country standards. Lastly I would like to say, the new office is very comfy and the trees (the lives ones, not the fake ones) and the large open view really make feel fresh.

post_title: Great Place for Growth, Learning, and Collaboration
full_review: I have had a positive experience working at ExpeedStudio. It is a company that offers a lot of opportunities, especially if you are eager to learn and grow professionally. The environment is very supportive for entry-level team members, with structured onboarding and guidance that makes it easier to settle in and progress. One of the standout aspects is the new headquarters. The office space is modern, comfortable, and equipped with everything you need to do your best work. It is clear that the leadership invests in making the workplace both efficient and enjoyable. Collaboration is a big part of the culture here. I have had the chance to work with some great teammates who are always open to sharing knowledge and helping each other. The CEO, in particular, is approachable and has a strong vision for the company. He genuinely cares about the teamтАЩs growth and well-being, which is something I really value. There have been some concerns raised about certain leadership styles, especially involving the CTO. While this may be true for some, I have noticed that the company is actively working on improving leadership and communication across departments. They are open to feedback and trying to create a more balanced environment for everyone. Overall, ExpeedStudio is a dynamic place where you can build a meaningful career. Like any company, it has its challenges, but I have seen real efforts being made to address them. If you are passionate, proactive, and willing to learn, this is a great place to be.

post_title: Toxic Culture with No Room for Growth
full_review: Promotions are not performance-based but rather depend on how upper management perceives you. The workplace is riddled with office politics, creating a toxic environment. Salary increments fall below industry standards, and there is little to no room for career growth, regardless of hard work or dedication. The absence of experienced senior professionals further hampers development and mentorship. Additionally, several office rules are unprofessional and unethical, showing little regard for employee well-being or satisfaction. Advice to Leadership: Implement a transparent, merit-based promotion system. Take active steps to eliminate toxic office politics. Ensure salary increments align with industry standards. Recognize and reward hard work and dedication. Hire experienced senior professionals to guide and mentor teams. Reevaluate and reform unprofessional office rules to prioritize employee satisfaction and ethical practices.

MD should introduce minimum facilities and need some mature leadership to regain the title of the best.

There are even rumors of this individual's influence extending into UCB (United Commercial Bank). Despite a substantial investment by UCB in this tech team, the dominance of this establishment is said to have hindered progress and driven away new management. It is also alleged that a former senior technology leader, who was instrumental in bringing the aforementioned influential individual into the organization, ultimately became a victim of their ambition.

full_review: In the past two years, all the good employees have left. Everyone who was at the senior level is now working in other companies. More or less, those who were at the senior level have been turned into team leads. Behind that, itтАЩs just us left. You canтАЩt even share any negative news with the managers; if you do, they immediately get upset. Managers seem to misunderstand what you say; they apparently donтАЩt know the difference between negative and positive. If someone wants to do something good, they find something bad in it and stop them from moving forward, telling them, тАЬYou just focus on your own project, you will get plenty of time for skill development.тАЭ Still, I care about the company тАФ the only reason being there are many friendly people around, and at one time there was a good mentor team lead. Here, apart from software engineers, no other engineers or brothers have any opportunity for career growth. There have been talks of changing the salary structure, but instead, dirty games have been played twice in the last two years. I donтАЩt like it here. The point is, I want to leave. But before leaving, I want to give some advice тАФ Instead of opening branches or agencies in the country or abroad, focus a bit on the development of current employees. Change the mindset of the managers. Make or hire good team leads. Take a bit of care for mid-level employees. If employees are happy, they will do all work with their own interest. post_title: Working at HubXpert тАУ A Place That Truly Cares
full_review: I've been working at HubXpert for over 2 years now, and to this day, IтАЩve never seriously thought about leaving. The management here genuinely looks after the teamтАФnot just as employees, but as people. That care has meant everything to me. A few months ago, I had an accident and couldnтАЩt come to the office for nearly half the month. I was officially on leave during that time. Friends and neighbors kept asking me, тАЬDo you still have your job?тАЭ I simply showed them a message from my phone and said, тАЬNot only do I still have my jobтАФthey paid my full salary for the month.тАЭ That moment summed up what makes HubXpert special. For a small startup, this kind of support and respect for its team is rareтАФand honestly, incredible. There are so many more positive stories I could shareтАФI could probably write a whole book. Sure, like any workplace, it has its flaws. But the good far outweighs the bad here. HubXpert isnтАЩt just a companyтАФit feels like a team that truly stands by you.

post_title: Serious Concerns About Discrimination in Recent Engineering Restructure
full_review: If you've heard about C3fa1o, you probably know that it's a great place to work in many ways. The work environment, engineering culture, and overall company values have traditionally been top-notch, truly an engineerтАЩs dream. However, the benefits like provident fund, gratuity, and insurance coverage could definitely use improvement. But what's most concerning recently is the way Cefalo restructured its engineering designations. This process has exposed serious issues of bias and inconsistency. There are currently four Engineering Managers (EMs), each with their own mindset and approach. Unfortunately, this has resulted in unfair treatment for many engineers. Some EMs overlooked capable and experienced engineers, undervaluing their contributions and not giving them the opportunities they deserved. On the other hand, some favored people close to them, prioritizing those relationships over merit and capability. As a result, we're seeing cases where engineers with 6 years of experience are promoted to Staff level, while others with over 12 years of solid technical background are placed at Level 2. Some might argue that years of experience donтАЩt always reflect ability but the inconsistencies go beyond that. For example, in the recent promotions to Senior Software Engineer II , several individuals with relatively little experience in senior-level architecture or tech stack were promoted, while more seasoned professionals were passed over. Right now, youтАЩll find: Engineers with 3.5 years of experience holding Senior Software Engineer II titles Engineers with 6 years being promoted to Staff And highly experienced engineers with 15 years of deep technical knowledge being labeled as Staff Software Engineers or even stuck at lower levels Does that sound fair or logical? These kinds of decisions send the wrong message to high-performing engineers. People with strong potential are being held back because of flawed evaluation criteria, personal biases, or internal politics. This leads to frustration, stagnation, and eventually, attrition. Cefalo needs to re-evaluate and address this apparent discrimination . If you donтАЩt recognize and reward your hardworking and talented people, they will leave. Engineers want to grow. They want leadership opportunities. They deserve to be assessed fairly, transparently, and consistently. Engineering Managers should empower , not block . Management should stand for fairness, growth, and opportunity not favoritism.

comments.comment_text: It's a matter of skills, not just year of experience, you have to understand it ok?

Yes, I believe part of the issue is that Engineering Managers (EMs) may not have a full understanding of all the engineers or developers under them. This can lead to misunderstandings. Some developers are doing exceptionally well, and others, while highly skilled, may be working in a limited tech stack based on project needs. Unfortunately, theyтАЩre often judged solely on that stack, rather than their full capabilities.
IтАЩve noticed that some developers are actually capable of much more than their current roles reflect. However, this potential is sometimes overlookedтАФpossibly due to a lack of direct communication. It seems that EMs may rely mainly on feedback from team leads or maybe just a small communication, which doesnтАЩt always provide a complete picture. This could be contributing to this discrimination or unfair evaluations.
I believe that if EMs made an effort to get to know each developer more directly or maybe knowing them well, they would gain better insights into their strengths and contributions. This could lead to more balanced recognition and a more supportive work environment.
[IMG-7834.jpg](https://postimg.cc/tsvqxCpB)
Thanks for the true words.

I'm not sure who you are, but your words truly touched my heart. Your comment doesn't seem to go against any company policies rather it feels like an honest and heartfelt expression.
The comment you shared reflects why some people might hesitate to approach Engineering Managers. Cefalo has always felt like a second home to many of us and while I've heard of cases where people reached out to EMs and came away feeling frustrated, I believe there's always room for open dialogue and understanding.
If you've spent even a short time at Cefalo, you'll know that our Managing Director (MD) is not only a strong leader but also a genuinely kind human being. I truly believe he would never let someone leave disappointed.
To the management: instead of viewing this as blame, I kindly request you to consider it as an opportunity to reflect and rethink. Honest feedback, even when emotional, can be a valuable guide for growth and improvement.ЁЯЩП

I respectfully disagree with the post. Cefalo has a culture that encourages open communication and values employee feedback. This has been evident in the recent structural changes where the management actively sought input before finalizing decisions.
┬а
If concerns arenтАЩt communicated, it becomes impossible for the management to address them. In case youтАЩre unhappy with any recent decisions, I strongly recommend reaching out to the appropriate channelsтАФwhether itтАЩs your EM, MD, or even Oslo management. All levels are open to discussion and feedback.
┬а
Additionally, questioning or demeaning a colleagueтАЩs promotion is both unprofessional and unfair. Unless youтАЩve worked closely with someone, itтАЩs difficult to fully understand their skills or leadership potential, which might have been recognized by clients or management.
┬а
Promotions are based on multiple factors including performance, communication, and leadership traitsтАФnot just years of experience. If your expectations differ, and you prefer a workplace where seniority outweighs skill, then perhaps a different environment would suit you better.

Thanks for raising this issue very maturely and politely. Totally agree with it. I never had the courage to approach about this to our MD, though he is always open to such conversations. I believe he and other people related with managements will take necessary steps regarding this concern even though it's among very few people.

To the person who commented below┬а
Saying тАЬpeople close to management always get priorityтАЭтАФthatтАЩs not just feedback, thatтАЩs a serious accusation. I get that people need to vent sometimes, and it's totally valid to feel frustrated. But if something genuinely feels off, there are channels to raise it. You donтАЩt even have to go through local management if youтАЩre uncomfortableтАФour CTO, COO, even the CEO are all from Norway and have always been surprisingly approachable.
Also, letтАЩs be honest: if nepotism was running the show, we wouldnтАЩt have made it this far. Companies built on favoritism usually start to rot from the insideтАФthey donтАЩt sustain growth for over a decade. Nepotism doesnтАЩt scale; it fractures teams, kills morale, and eventually shows up in the results. Whatever flaws we might haveтАФand every company has someтАФI donтАЩt think thatтАЩs the foundation weтАЩre standing on.

Each and every point mentioned in this post is true. Specially the EM's perspective and clear biasness in designation change. It seems like people close to the management gets always priority. And probably those people got offended by this post.
Cefalo is good in most of the cases and one of the best company in BD without any doubt. But no one is out of mistakes. So I believe cefalo should acknowledge these concerns being raised by their employees and should look into it happily.

I have to respectfully disagree. Speaking from personal experience in this industry, I genuinely believe Cefalo has one of the fairest recognition systems IтАЩve seen. Promotions here arenтАЩt just handed out randomlyтАФtheyтАЩre based on actual merit: skills, ownership, leadership, and all the intangible qualities that make someone a strong fit for this place.
You mentioned:
тАЬEngineers with 3.5 years of experience holding Senior Software Engineer II titles.тАЭ
Why not? If someone consistently shows the depth, maturity, and capability expected from a senior engineer, then whatтАЩs stopping us from acknowledging it? Would it really be more just to wait for an arbitrary year count to pass before recognizing talent? That feels more like box-checking than leadership.
Honestly, most of the remapping decisions Cefalo made this time seem pretty aligned with the growth IтАЩve observed in people around me.
Now, if promotions were strictly tied to tenureтАФlike тАЬX years = Y titleтАЭтАФwouldnтАЩt that be unfair? ThatтАЩs not recognition, thatтАЩs time-based entitlement. And using a word like тАЬdiscriminationтАЭ in this context feels a bit heavy-handed, to be honest.
Also, if thereтАЩs something bothering you deeply, why not take it to your Engineering Manager? Or better yetтАФwalk into the MDтАЩs office. IтАЩve done that literally hundreds of times, sometimes for the tiniest things. He listens. ThatтАЩs not just a sloganтАФitтАЩs what an open-door policy actually looks like.

My first question to you have you reached to either EM / MD? If not you, then you should do that first and ask for explanation rather posting here.┬аFor similar pupose I reached out MD direclty and asked for justified reasons and he gave clear indications to me where I am lacking.Also when a new structure is imposed, that will not be perfect from the begaining.┬а

While aspiring to a higher title for yourself is natural, designations must match demonstrated skills and responsibilities. Cefalo rewards impact and leadership тАФ juniors who consistently exceed expectations can earn higher titles.
I have noticed many colleagues have already reviewed their new designations one-on-one with their Engineering Managers, who explained the criteria. If you havenтАЩt yet, please discuss your designation with your manager тАФ they can detail the specific factors management considered.
Cefalo welcome direct questions тАФ reach out to your manager instead of leaving anonymous feedback so they can address your concerns.

That's not entirely true. This is a new structure from management and it is not completely perfect. Having said that, this is not fixed as well. Individuals can contact management people to get insights on the decision. If there is a mistake, management will address it. If there's viable reasons, management will be open to you about it. I am saying this because I faced this as well and I know other people also had an open conversation with the management and I provided the summary above. I do understand that we want management to be fair and most of us are not comfortable talking with the management directly about this as we don't have prior information on what is happening with others and sometimes being afraid of the job market. But I would suggest to have a discussion with the management first so that there is no hesitation or confusion in the mind. What is mentioned in the post about promotion and experience is true but the reasons for the promotion is not entirely true.

That's literally true. Thanks for a polite review against the discrimination. This is something Cefalo should reconsider. Our MD can ask EMs to clarify their feedback based on which criteria they considerd individual to be mapped.┬а

post_title: Worst Environment and Behaviour
full_review: I had a highly disappointing experience with Trenza Software. The company has a problematic work environment and a toxic workplace culture. One of the most concerning practices was requiring new employees to submit their main academic certificates just to join, which felt excessive and created a sense of mistrust. If you leave the company, they don't give your certificate easily. The leadership, including the CEO, often displayed unprofessional behavior, with communication that was rude and disrespectful. Overall, the lack of professionalism, combined with the negative work culture, made working at Trenza Software an unpleasant experience. I do not recommend this company to anyone seeking a positive and respectful workplace. If you check this company on glassdoor, you will see 1.8 star.

post_title: Wrapped in Care, Drenched in Toxicity
full_review: This organization is led by a husband and wife, where the CEO and COO operate the company out of their own residence. Unfortunately, they treat employees more like subordinates than professionals. Despite employees' dedication and hard work, they are often denied basic respect and professional boundaries. Taking a day off before or after a weekendтАФcommonly known as "sandwich leave"тАФis strictly prohibited. Even in emergencies, employees must follow up repeatedly, only to hear that the decision depends entirely on the COOтАЩs mood. Although an HR department exists in name, all authority is centralized. HR personnel have no power to make independent decisions. Salary disbursements are frequently delayedтАФsometimes until the 15th or 20th of the month. Bonuses are nonexistent. The overall culture is defined by micromanagement, distrust, and poor communication. In such an environment, professional growth and employee well-being are severely compromised. If you're considering a role hereтАФthink twice. You deserve a workplace that values and respects its people.

post_title: Selise Digital: Where Politics Trump Performance
full_review: At Selise Digital, a toxic leadership culture often overshadows talent and hard work. Team leads and unit heads frequently prioritize favoritism over merit, promoting those who align personally rather than professionally. Many lack updated technical skills, yet micromanage tasks they barely understand. Constructive feedback is dismissed, and a blame culture thrivesтАФwhere success is claimed by leads, and failure dumped on juniors. Knowledge is gatekept, career growth is undefined, and overwork is normalized without appreciation. Instead of nurturing a healthy, innovative environment, leadership often fosters fear, stagnation, and political games.

ItтАЩs easy to throw around dramatic one-liners like тАЬPolitics trump performanceтАЭ when youтАЩve never actually performed.
LetтАЩs get real. SELISE, like any serious tech company, rewards value, not victimhood. If your strategy for growth involves whining on social media instead of learning, building, or leading, then yes, your career will stagnate. And no, itтАЩs not the companyтАЩs fault. ItтАЩs yours.
You claim тАЬleads lack technical skillsтАЭ while conveniently ignoring the countless engineers who started as juniors and now lead major units after proving themselves. You cry about тАЬmicromanagementтАЭ while skipping deadlines. You throw tantrums about тАЬblame cultureтАЭ when your own delivery is full of bugs. And you rant about тАЬgatekeeping knowledgeтАЭ while refusing to ask questions, collaborate, or upskill.
Not everyone who fails was a victim of injustice. Sometimes, a madarchod just couldnтАЩt do the job.
SELISE isnтАЩt perfect, no company is. But for those who are hungry, adaptable, and relentless, the opportunities are real. Promotions happen. Recognition happens. Careers take off. If that didnтАЩt happen for you, ask yourself why.
Before calling out a тАЬtoxic culture,тАЭ take a long, hard look in the mirror. Sometimes, the culture isnтАЩt toxic. Sometimes, the ego is.And congratulations on using chatgpt. No wonder why your "career growth is undefined".

post_title: Behind the Curtain: What ItтАЩs Really Like Working Here
full_review: At first glance, this company might seem like a stable place to grow your career. But once you step inside, the experience tells a very different story. LetтАЩs start with one of the most basic expectations for any working professional тАФ salary. While pay is officially scheduled for the 10th of every month, it often gets delayed. It's not unusual for employees to receive their salaries well past that date, with no proper communication or explanation. This kind of unpredictability makes it incredibly difficult to plan financially and erodes trust over time. The quality of work also leaves much to be desired. If you're part of the QA team, prepare yourself for a purely manual testing environment. There's little to no emphasis on automation, and innovation is not exactly encouraged. Anyone hoping to sharpen their skills or adopt industry-standard tools will likely be disappointed. The situation isn't much better when it comes to the food. The companyтАЩs lunch system is poorly organized and offers substandard meals. It often feels like an afterthought rather than a basic employee benefit. You quickly learn to lower your expectations тАФ or bring your own food. Then thereтАЩs the codebase, which can only be described as chaotic. The coding structure is inconsistent and lacks proper standards. It becomes clear that quality and scalability werenтАЩt priorities during development. For developers who value clean, maintainable code, working here can be mentally draining. Unfortunately, the problems donтАЩt end with the systems тАФ they extend to people, too. The founder, Mr. 94w$h46 , has a reputation for occasional outbursts and unprofessional behavior. ItтАЩs not something that happens daily, but when it does, it leaves a lasting impact on the team. Respect and empathy from leadership shouldnтАЩt be a luxury, yet here, it often feels that way. What makes the environment even more frustrating is the double standard in rules. The company enforces strict policies on employees, expecting punctuality and discipline тАФ yet the owners themselves often ignore these same rules. It sends a clear message about the lack of fairness and consistency. And then there's HR. Instead of being a support system for employees, HR seems more focused on keeping management happy. TheyтАЩre always polite on the surface, but rarely helpful when real issues arise. Their approach often comes across as insincere тАФ or, as some say, just plain oily. In summary, this company may function on paper, but behind the scenes, the reality is filled with disappointment, inconsistency, and a lack of professionalism. post_title: Scam master!
full_review: Let me start from the beginning. During the interview, they will say many things that might seem impressive, but their salary range is far below what you would expect. They hire juniors for around 15,000! They will talk about profit sharing, provident fund facilities, and other perks. But guess what? The amount you can expect is hardly 10,000 after a fiscal year. Even my maid earns more than that in bonuses throughout the year. And donтАЩt get me started on increments; they will hold your increment for two years, waiting for people to become frustrated and quit. When you do leave, they wonтАЩt give you the increment money or the bonus that you rightfully earned. There are around 400 employees, but no HR department. In fact, itтАЩs essentially a one-man organization. Every decision comes from him, and he is incredibly narcissistic. Although there is a product and design team, he does whatever he pleases, undermining all the young talent he hired. ItтАЩs amusing to see him on LinkedIn, giving grand lectures on corruption when he is, in fact, the most corrupt person in the organization. Bdjobs had great potential, but it canтАЩt grow as it should because of his narrow-minded and money-driven mindset. Companies like this are suited for those who lack hope and ambition for their careers. The administration and management operate unethically, draining employees of their money and talents. If you are still there, I urge you to RUN AS SOON AS YOU CAN!

post_title: Manager, senior engineers, and QA leads create a very toxic environment, disrespect employees.
full_review: The salary structure is extremely poor. The manager, a few senior engineers, and QA leads foster a highly toxic environment, consistently disrespecting employees. They exhibit unprofessional behavior, treating employees as if they were servants. Overtime is unpaid, yet employees are forced to work beyond regular hours almost daily and cannot clock out without permission after their shift ends. The QA leads display monstrous, unprofessional behavior, frequently using toxic and rude language that demoralizes employees. They also steal teammatesтАЩ credit, with the manager attributing all achievements to the QA leads. Additionally, QA leads deliberately give poor annual reviews to justify minimal yearly increments.

post_title: Great CTO | No Overtime for a startup | Great place to start a career
full_review: A place where you can start you software engineer journey. You will be able to work on some small and interesting projects and if you perform well, you may work on some big projects as well. The CTO is great. If you join the company, just get as much knowledge as you can from him. When I was there, I felt maybe I was gaining a little knowledge from here. But after going to another company working in a bigger project, I realized I learned a lot from him. Even those who left the company after 1.5 to 2 years, they are in very good places. Pros: 1. The CTO always thinks about the employees. He will forbid you even to give 10 minutes outside you working hours. 2. The CTO will take a one to one interview once a year and really tries to solve the issues if it is in the budget. 3. Small team, no politics. 4. Hybrid office. even the times are flexible. Even if it is a startup, no chance of lay off. Cons: 1. As the CTO is good, the team has great potential. But no efforts from the CEO or the business side. 2. No benefits, just the salary. Advise: This company have that ability to make an average engineer to a great one. a lot of potential. but needs more projects. Dear CEO, please try to bring some projects as we all know who worked here, that Orbit Informatics can be a great Company under the mighty CTO.

post_title: A good and friendly software company in Sylhet
full_review: Pros: -Salary on time -Yearly increment -Profit share -Two fastive bonus -Yearly tour (opportunities for international tour) -Good ceo and hr Cons: -Employees have too much artificial behaviour. -Management should focus on everyone, just not to be team lead centric. post_title: Best Workplace in Bangladesh
full_review: I have been working at Cefalo for over six years, and throughout this time, it has felt like much more than just a workplaceтАФit has truly become my second home. Whenever I encountered any challenges, I was able to raise them openly with the management, who always listened attentively, provided thoughtful feedback, and took appropriate action. During these years, I have consistently given my bestтАФputting in 100% effort for the company I deeply value. In return, I have always received appreciation in the form of positive feedback, promotions, salary increments, and other benefits. I have never had to worry about my career growth here. Keep up the great work, Cefalo! You have my heartfelt best wishes for continued success.

post_title: When Leadership Lost Its Way
full_review: This company used to be a great place to work, with strong leadership and a positive environment. But things have changed a lot after new management took over. One big problem is the behavior of some leaders. For example, a top employee from management openly threatened employeesтАЩ careers during a project retro meeting. IтАЩve also heard similar stories about this person from others. This kind of behavior creates fear instead of trust. Management now seems more focused on impressing the headquarters in Korea than supporting local staff. HR doesnтАЩt seem to understand how to work with tech teams, and good suggestions from employees are often ignored. Because of this toxic environment, I decided to leave. I hope the company realizes what's going wrong and works to create a better, more respectful place to work again.

[Management Failures] Team leads and department heads seem more focused on pleasing the MD than on driving the product vision. ThereтАЩs no alignment between strategic decisions and actual deliverables. [Unfair Layoffs] Seasoned professionals are being let go in the name of тАЬAI initiatives,тАЭ yet thereтАЩs no clear plan or roadmap behind these cuts. [Subpar Work Environment] Basic office suppliesтАФtissues, mouse batteries, notebooks, pensтАФmust be purchased out of pocket. The restrooms are in a dire state, and the workspace feels more like a bustling ferry terminal than a modern office. [Total Employee Neglect] No salary increments; promotions are reserved only for C-level executives and their inner circle. Company events like picnics, iftars, and tours must be funded personally. ThereтАЩs no real system of performance appraisal. [Hassle Around Time Off] Requesting leave feels like admitting a crime: тАЬWhen will you be away?тАЭ тАЬWhy do you need time off?тАЭ тАЬHow will your work get done?тАЭ [Lack of Genuine Strategy] Everything is reduced to meeting KPIs on paper. ThereтАЩs no sustainable plan or long-term roadmap.

post_title: Culture of Trust and Empowerment
full_review: After spending more than five years at Cefalo, I can confidently say this is a workplace built on trust and empowerment. IтАЩve always been given the freedom to take initiative, make decisions, and own my responsibilities without micromanagement. What makes it even better is the approachable leadershipтАФevery time IтАЩve had feedback or ideas, they were heard and acted upon. It feels amazing to be part of a culture that values initiative and mutual respect.

post_title: Very good company and CEO with few cons
full_review: Pros - Standard salary, stable jobs - Standard yearly increment - Understands and considers employees need and personal problems - Advance Salary on Eid or before yearly tour - Free Breakfast and lunch - Yearly long tour and day tour - Yearly profit share and bonus, recognition - Friendly work culture Cons: (Not much) - Monthly Salary Deduction based on due or incomplete hours - No employee structure, they don't maintain employee levels or structure in the office, very much needed as they're not startup anymore (should implement soon) - they donтАЩt remove toxic persons from the office even after multiple complains

post_title: Toxic as hell
full_review: I had a very disappointing experience working here. The management structure is highly unprofessional. Employees are often hired for one role (e.g., SD) and then moved to entirely different roles (e.g., WD) without prior discussion or consent. This bait-and-switch approach creates confusion and dissatisfaction from the beginning. The work culture is extremely toxic. Even within the same department, colleagues seem to operate with their own individual agendas, offering no real sense of teamwork or collaboration. The probation period, officially stated as 3 months, often extends to 6 months or more without clear justification or feedback. Meetings are frequently called over minor issues, creating unnecessary stress rather than promoting solutions. Leadership appears more focused on enforcing rules on employees, yet they don't lead by example. For instance, even basic standards like dress code are ignored by some higher-level staff. Overall, there is a lack of professionalism, accountability, and genuine care for employee well-being. I would not recommend this company to those seeking a healthy work environment or fair career development.

post_title: A Masterclass in Toxic Leadership: My Experience at the Worst Office Ever
full_review: Absolute worst office to work for ever. If you want career growth by learning a new tech stack and upskilling yourself by doing new work, then this company is not for you. The CEO is the absolute worst person you can ever find. The more 'tel' you can give, the more he'll like you. If you're not skilled enough to be a CTO or don't have any valid experience, that's okay. All you need to do is give more 'tel' and 'pump' to the CEO; you'll be given that. It's like a bunch of kids running a company who don't know how to manage employees or keep them happy. Let me give one example of how unprofessional the CEO is. They invited everyone with spouses to a certain lunch; later on, HR told everyone spouses were not included except for managerial (read pa chata) positions. Why can't you decide first what you want before giving an official notice to all employees? There were no apologies or anything. This unprofessional CEO treats this office as his own playground. Also, in the name of company expansion, he recently hired 4 people, but after only a mere three months, he fired 3 of them without giving a proper explanation. Like, why don't you vet enough first before hiring if you think their personality doesn't fit with your company? How immature you are. He says that all employees are his family and hoards their weekend time for his extracurricular activities (without any overtime). There is invisible pressure to join these certain activities. If you do not, then you'll be indirectly shunned. Also, in the last 4-day, 3-night (weekend included) so-called unofficial office tour, this unprofessional CEO threw tantrums every now and then about why everyone wasnтАЩt giving him enough attention 24/7. If you want attention, you shouldтАЩve made it a one-day tour, not a freaking 4-day one. He made a 4-day itinerary of ful-tokka, mangsho chor, pillow passing, etc. games. Who does that? Even the CEOтАЩs wife didnтАЩt attend a lot of the games, but he was pressuring all employees to attend them. The only pro I see of working in this office is that itтАЩs a hybrid setup; you only need to go to the office two days a week.

post_title: One of the most underrated companies of the country
full_review: Serving here for more than a year and being surprised every day with their professionalism, care to the employees, work culture, empathy and so many things that they are trying to manage for their team members. Pros: 1. On time salary, bonuses, profit share etc. 2. Learning friendly work environment 3. Excellent work culture with nice work environment 4. Full subsidized lunch, snacks, tea, coffee etc. (Food quality is too good) 5. Leave encashment & medical allowance facility 6. Earn, Sick, Casual leaves. Some special leaves like Paternal leave, Marriage leave, Recreational leave (40% Gross Salary) 7. Profit share & performance bonus 8. Yearly grand retreat 9. Different days celebration in the office etc. Cons: Company should focus in developing new own products which they are already trying to. Apart from this there is no other mentionable cons.

post_title: Brilliance Lost: A Company That CouldтАЩve Built the Future
full_review: It was once considered one of the most promising AI/ML companiesтАФa joint venture with ACI. The company brought together some truly brilliant minds and had a team of highly talented, passionate individuals. With the right direction, they had the potential to build something on the scale of Amazon. Unfortunately, they ended up focusing on smaller, poorly executed products that didnтАЩt reflect the team's capabilities. In the early years (first 3тАУ4 years), the company showed immense potential. The CTO was a visionary and one of the brightest minds there. However, it's unclear whether the issue was a gap in his vision or an inability to align with or execute under the CEO's direction. The CEO, Badrul, unfortunately lacked the leadership qualities required to scale a tech-driven company. His poor client-handling skills and overall lack of strategic insight significantly contributed to the companyтАЩs downfall. Despite these leadership flaws, the internal environment was quite positive. Salaries were competitive, and there was strong potential for career growth. Employees had the freedom to experiment with new technologies and even apply them directly to live projectsтАФmaking it an excellent place to learn and innovate. The workplace culture was another highlight. Most employees were exceptionally talented and supportive, fostering a collaborative and friendly atmosphere. Leadership opportunities were open to anyone willing to step upтАФinitiative was welcomed and encouraged. However, not everything was perfect. The food, sourced from ACI, left much to be desired. On the bright side, the transport facility provided was a major perk and made commuting convenient. Unfortunately, the company's financial situation began to deteriorate due to a lack of stable clients and projects. Poor client acquisition and retention strategies led to a decline in revenue, making it difficult to sustain operations. Eventually, these issues forced the company to shut downтАФa sad end for what could have been a market leader in AI and machine learning.

This kind of pseudo-positivity is harmful тАФ not just to society, but even to yourself. When something is wrong, it must be called out clearly and loudly. Sugarcoating injustice only enables it.

Whoever commented. Take a deep breath, cool down. Life happens. Rage and anger destroy a person. What happened with you was not good but cheris the moment where you had a great journey once, it was a nice working place wasnтАЩt it? The people were beautiful and brought lots of good memories didnтАЩt they? Take that and leave the anger/frustration behind. In life there are much more to come. Shit happens and embrace that within you and it will make you strong.┬а
Wishing you best of luck and great life

post_title: Only CXO and Principal (Sde, Qa, Etc) are making money.
full_review: Some Principal Engineers try to do everything themselves, while others barely contribute..yet both types end up taking all the credit, as if no one else even exists. The organization seems built entirely around Principal (SDEs, Operations, QA) and CXOs, who design internal policies to channel compensations from Robi into their own circle. ItтАЩs more like a syndicate than a company, where mid-level and junior engineers are overworked, underpaid, and ignored. Take this for example: freshers are hired at just 35k, even after 3 years they barely cross 50k .. i mean wtf!. Seriously, what kind of growth is that? IтАЩve heard they offer better entry level salaries to iut and buet grads, which just adds to the inequality. For a mid-level engineer, this place is a dead end, no growth, just politics and exploitation. If you value your career, get out fast. And to Mr. Z** and H****, keep the motivational Bullshits coming. letтАЩs see how long you can keep milking these engineers.

post_title: Bdgobs.com is Overrated тАУ My Honest Experience
full_review: I worked at Bdgobs.com, and honestly, it was one of the worst job experiences IтАЩve had. 1. Poor Work Environment: The office looks fancy on the outside, but inside itтАЩs not employee-friendly at all. ThereтАЩs only one shared bathroom for everyone, and itтАЩs not well-maintained. ThereтАЩs no proper place to eat lunch, so many people eat at their desks or in random corners. Also, there are too many security cameras watching you all the timeтАФit felt like we were being watched more than trusted. 2. Bad Management: The management is very controlling. You donтАЩt get to share your ideas or opinions. If you try, they donтАЩt take it seriously. The CEO is known for shouting at employees and treating them with no respect. Team leads donтАЩt support the juniors much eitherтАФthey only care about showing results to the higher-ups, even if that means pressuring you or blaming you when something goes wrong. 3. Low Salary & Fake Promises: The salary is very low compared to how much work they expect. When I joined, they promised bonuses and performance rewards, but most of that never came. ThereтАЩs no proper salary structure. Some people who work less get paid more just because they are close to management. 4. Toxic Team Leads: Many team leads act more like bullies than leaders. Instead of guiding or helping, they just pass pressure down from management. They don't care about your workload or if you're stuckтАФthey only care about numbers and deadlines. If something goes wrong, theyтАЩre quick to blame juniors instead of taking responsibility. Promotions are often based on favoritism, not performance. Some leaders even gossip about team members, comment on their personal things, or create a toxic environment with their attitude. 5. No Career Growth: There are no learning opportunities or proper training. You do the same kind of repetitive work every day. If you want to improve your skills or grow in your career, youтАЩre on your own. Team leads don't mentor or supportтАФthey just push tasks without explaining properly. 5. Toxic Culture & Poor Work-Life Balance: You are expected to stay late almost every day, even if you finish your work on time. ThereтАЩs no appreciation for hard work, just more pressure. Taking leave is very difficultтАФespecially if youтАЩre new or in the probation period. Sick leave is rarely approved, and HR doesnтАЩt support the employees much. Final Thoughts: Bdjobs.com looks good from the outside, but working here is very stressful and demotivating. ThereтАЩs no appreciation, only pressure. Freshers will be overworked and ignored. Experienced people will feel stuck and frustrated. The team leads are more like mini-bosses with no leadership skills, and the overall work culture is toxic. I strongly suggest thinking twice before joining.

post_title: Bangladeshi Google
full_review: I had a frustrating experience with We11DevтАЩs hiring process, marked by unreasonable expectations and unprofessional behavior. The process involved an excessive number of interview rounds with little added value, along with unpaid and overly complex take-home assignments. There was also a clear disregard for standard notice periods, expecting instant availability. Interviewers were often late or canceled without notice, and some displayed a condescending attitude. The scheduling and overall communication were disorganized, and the job description turned out to be vague and misleading, with shifting responsibilities and misaligned expectations. Ultimately, the lack of any constructive feedback after rejection made the experience even more discouraging.

post_title: Great Work Environment with Supportive Management
full_review: I've had a genuinely positive experience working at this company. The management is extremely supportive and always prioritizes employee well-being. One of the things I appreciate most is the flexibility тАФ the company follows a hybrid work model, which allows us to work from home for an entire month if needed. When working from the office, the environment is equally pleasant. The lunch provided is delicious and makes office days something to look forward to. The entire team is full of respectful and well-mannered individuals, and thereтАЩs absolutely no office politics, which creates a healthy and professional atmosphere. In terms of leave policies and other facilities, the company is fair and considerate. Overall, it's a great place to work with a strong balance between productivity and employee satisfaction.
